text: in the UK, EU, Afghanistan, and PakistanThe British government’s Foreign and Commonwealth Office recently released data showing a number of foreign spies suspected of having breached UK government surveillance systems may not be the only perpetrators. The Office of Strategic Services (OSS) released data showing that in addition to an already known list of British spies with high-risk intelligence, a total of 12 suspected terrorists have been questioned by British security services with information suggesting that they may have also accessed UK systems that are being monitored by the NSA. These suspects include:• A “person of interest” in a 2007 shooting at the London Stock Exchange that resulted in four fatalities, and one police officer being seriously injured.• The former chief of Pakistan’s national intelligence agency, who reportedly fled to the US in 2009 after being questioned by UK intelligence about his role in the assassination of Benazir Bhutto.• Pakistani-born suspect Abdul Hafiz, who had reportedly traveled to the UK under false pretenses, and was questioned by the OSS in late 2006 in the case of an alleged plot to kill a British soldier.• Abdul Rahman, a suspect in the murder of a police officer that took place the following year, who was questioned by the UK security service (CIS) after being “identified as a possible suspect in the death of Detective Constable David James,” who had been involved in the investigation into the death of two men who were murdered in a suspected murder-for-hire plot.• A suspect in the 2006 murder of a police officer, who was reportedly involved in the investigation into the case and who was questioned by the CIS.In addition, the British government revealed that in an effort to protect UK spy targets, intelligence sources were sent overseas to question suspects. In the UK, for instance, intelligence sources were sent to the US to question suspects linked to the 2007 London Stock Exchange shooting. In the US, the same sources were flown to Pakistan to question suspects associated with a 2006 “plot to murder a British soldier at a NATO base in the country,” though the source of the attack remains a mystery. In some cases, the source of the attack has still not been identified.The information released by the British government to the OSS shows that a number of the suspects were under suspicion but that some have not been arrested.

The United States should try a range of diplomatic tactics, including military, to ensure that Kim Jong Un doesn’t possess the capability to use nuclear weapons against its neighbours, a group of analysts said today.“Kim Jong Un has clearly seen that the United States doesn’t have any credible ability to deter him from using nuclear weapons and he has turned to the long game in order to achieve his goals,” says William Frey of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.This is not good news for North Korea, because now US forces will be in South Korea in case it decides to attack South Korea with nukes.That is all, no weapons tests or anything. He is going to be very worried about that. I don’t know how that will go. But I think that the US military is probably going to want to be very close to the base if Kim Jong Un tries something. That would probably be the end of the strategy of getting to Pyongyang.I think that the US would prefer to see an economic relationship, and that would also be something that we do have.The analyst thinks that any US military action against North Korea would probably lead to another attack by North Korea.And he warns that Kim Jong Un would have no choice but to invade South Korea if the US does anything to him.So I think that the US strategy will be to get as close as they can to South Korea. That will probably be to the port in Pyeongchang. I don’t know how that will go but that is part of the plan.But I think that the US and other nations should probably look at a range of diplomatic techniques, including military ones, in order to make sure that Kim Jong Un’s regime doesn’t have the capacity to launch a nuclear strike against its neighbours.North Korea may not be using nuclear weapons against US forces in the near future, but the chances of its regime going nuclear are rising every day.This could lead to Kim Jong Un trying to build nuclear weapons that have a greater effect than conventional weapons.

A Jewish woman sits on the sidewalk outside a mosque in New York that has been closed to men after a similar incident in a different U.S. city on Wednesday.TOM BORGES, Associated PressThe Jewish woman is taking an unusual step in New York City for a second day, to make a public statement to the police after an incident in which a Jewish man was refused entry at a New York mosque.The woman is taking an unusual step in New York City for a second day, to make a public statement to the police after an incident in which a Jewish man was refused entry at a New York mosque.The man who was refused entry at the mosque in lower Manhattan spoke to The Associated Press on Friday evening.On Thursday, he said he wanted to attend the mosque service on Friday, but had to turn away when he was turned away. He said it was because Muslims are not allowed to enter during prayers.The incident came a day after police officers escorted a Jewish man into a synagogue and allowed him inside.There have been multiple incidents in recent weeks where Muslim-majority mosques have barred men from attending services.The New York police department said Friday that the man who was refused entry at the mosque has a complaint pending with it. The police department declined to provide further information.The incident is not a national problem. There are no major mosques in the United States that have barred men from attendance in recent years, and there is no report of incidents in which men have been turned away because they are Jewish.But there have been several incidents in which groups of Muslims have attacked and defaced Jewish symbols in response to such incidents.There have been multiple incidents in recent weeks where Muslim-majority mosques have barred men from attending services.

in Sambisa ForestOn 15 December 2017, the Chief Justice of Nigeria, Justice Dikumo, handed a letter requesting the International Criminal Court to consider taking a full investigation of atrocities committed by Boko Haram in the Sambisa Forest. This request was submitted as a statement of Nigeria's intention to take action against atrocities by Boko Haram. Nigeria's actions are in response to a letter of request sent to the ICC by the U.S. State Department in 2014.Amnesty International's request for action against crimes committed by Boko Haram is an important step in the ongoing struggle to end crimes against humanity perpetrated by Boko Haram.Boko Haram is responsible for committing atrocities on a horrific scale against civilians in Nigeria's Sambisa Forest, where over 250,000 people were displaced and some 300,000 people have fled their homes. The Sambisa Forest has been declared as a humanitarian crisis because its nature, scale and magnitude of destruction make it difficult to provide food for all displaced people in need.The Sambisa Forest has been subjected to extensive destruction, including the destruction of more than half a million trees and a significant number of animal farms in order to ensure Boko Haram's operational activities.Amnesty International is concerned that it is now increasingly clear that many of these crimes were committed at the hands of armed groups who use the forest to carry out their operations and have caused serious humanitarian concern for the people living in and near the forest.The situation calls for a full investigation into these crimes, which would enable full accountability and accountability for those responsible. The United States of America also needs to take action to ensure that the crimes committed by these armed groups are fully investigated and properly punished.Boko Haram's brutal persecution of thousands of people for the crime of trying to leave the Sambisa Forest and return to their homes, is an urgent humanitarian issue in need of urgent attention. This attack should serve as a call for an international investigation into the Sambisa Forest crimes committed by Boko Haram and a call to the ICC to prosecute war criminals.In a letter to Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari on 2 December 2017, Nigeria's Justice Minister, and Attorney General of the Federation (AGF), Abubakar Malami, confirmed Nigeria's intention to take action against atrocities committed by Boko Haram.It is now time for the ICC to initiate an investigation and to fully investigate the crimes committed in Sambisa Forest.

Former Haitian dictator Jovenel Moïse is reportedly looking to stand in the next presidential election, said the son of the ex-president who's now living in Florida.The son, Laurent Duvernay-Tardif, made the comments in an interview with NBC Miami radio's "The Dave Campbell Show" posted to the website The Miami Herald."I think he is thinking about it," said Laurent."I think the question is whether he knows it and is ready to take the steps necessary to become an elected leader."Laurent said that he thinks he has a "lot of respect" for Moïse and a "good working relationship" with his ex-president father.In a follow-up interview with the Miami Herald on the same day, Laurent said that he thinks Moïse is "a good person, he's a good man. I think his father made a mistake when he gave away that power. The people were upset, that's what led to the change."But he noted that "he was a bad man and it's not the same man that I'm used to."And he admitted to the Herald that he thinks Moïse's power could be used to "help the people" even if he doesn't win a fifth term.He said that he's been keeping an eye on Moïse's health and that "everything I know about my dad is positive."Asked about allegations that Moïse sought to get himself elected president in the 2016 election, Laurent said: "I think there was some electioneering but I don't believe there was a real election."He noted that Moïse had said that he wanted to be president of Haiti, not of Haiti."If Moïse had done that, the people would have been in favor of his candidacy," said Laurent. "The people were not behind Moïse during his term and the Haitian people were not behind him during his second term."Laurent said he thinks the former dictator has "a lot of things he'd like to do.""

British Prime Minister Theresa May has been fighting back tears after President Donald Trump said she was "not quite right" and that he'd "probably give me a card" after his first meeting with May in the Oval Office.After Trump praised May for her negotiating skills and said that May had earned "very high ratings," he then hit her on everything from trade to the NHS.He talked about how the US is the UK's largest trading partner, but that that would change after Brexit."I don't want to make too many changes, we've got great trade deals but I think we've got to go into negotiations a little bit differently, but you understand," Trump said in the Oval Office."She was not happy with the deal, she wasn't happy with what happened, but she wasn't happy with what was going on before, either," Trump continued.Trump said that he would have "probably given her a card" but that he had "no interest" in becoming Prime Minister.The British leader immediately tried to respond by saying: "I can only say I'm very happy to have been able to make a positive and very substantial deal with the United States.""That's what this about. It's not about me," Trump replied. "She was very upset with me, and I understand."The president, however, admitted that he wouldn't be "happy" to make any peace agreement with the UK, even if it was good for both sides."I'm gonna get along with everybody, but I really don't care about the UK."The Prime Minister was already being praised by the president, and received a hero's welcome from her own cabinet, but the meeting caused another rift in her party, The Times of London reported.

World. (File Image)BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec 19 (Reuters) - Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's win in a general election on Sunday could trigger a power struggle within the ruling alliance that could split the main opposition parties, analysts said.Prayuth's election victory has raised hopes among his supporters of restoring Thai democracy, but those hopes could also lead to conflict between his two main rival parties, the Future Forward party led by former Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, and an opposition alliance led by former Deputy PM Prasit Doophanop, both of whom have said they are prepared to sit together in a new Thai-led government.Prayuth's party won 35% of the vote, just shy of the 38% needed for a simple majority in parliament and a parliamentary majority to enact laws, but both the Future Forward and Prasit parties have been under pressure to sit together in a new government after both parties won more than 10% of the vote in a separate national survey.But Prasit and Future Forward, whose supporters have demanded an immediate power-sharing agreement, have so far stuck with their pledge of holding "pre-vote consultations" to discuss which party or candidates to support in future elections.Future Forward said in a statement it was prepared to "agree or disagree" with any political party, but said it would not sit with a "fascist regime" and urged the public to rally on Sunday in support of the party and the government."If Prayuth's party is accepted by both Prasit's party and Future Forward's party in a government, the future is very bright," said Somsak Setboonach, political science lecturer at Thammasat University."However, this will be difficult if the Future Forward party and Prasit's party fail to work together as one government, as both parties will have different interests and views on future politics."Thammasat University Political Science Professor Chotisol Tatsirasri said that Prasit and Future Forward had similar aims and would work for an independent administration in a post-war Thailand.But he added that the two parties had different strategies to achieve the goal."

NominationThe Senate will begin its second day of debate on the nomination of Judge Sonia Sotomayor to become the next Supreme Court justice, after a long day of questions in which the Republicans took advantage of the Democrats' poor performances in the first full day of hearings. Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) questioned the nominee on the definition of judicial activism, and asked whether she had spoken to the Boston Tea Party, and whether her father had worked as a barber in a public housing project. Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) asked about the "prejudice" of President Obama, his wife Michelle, and his daughters Malia, 13, and Sasha, 11, referring to the former president's family vacation to Martha's Vineyard in 2012. Sotomayor's answers to his questions will likely be read as the first indications of how her supporters and detractors will interpret her. In response to a question from Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), Sotomayor responded that the Obama administration has violated the Constitution's pledge to be a "charity" in the form of the government's welfare programs, and that "it is shameful and wrong to reward political cronies by expanding their welfare rolls." Asked by Paul if he would vote for Sotomayor for the Supreme Court, the nominee said that she would. Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), who is considered the most likely Republican to vote against Sotomayor, was absent in the hearing.

A newly released video by a U.S. Army major-general that aims to provide Islamabad with a military strategy for stabilization of Afghanistan shows how the American strategy for Afghanistan has evolved. For the past several years, the U.S. strategy for Afghanistan was primarily centered around counter-terrorism and military presence. But since the withdrawal of U.S. troops in April, U.S. military strategy has changed. It has shifted toward countering the Taliban, especially in the south.In a video released last week by Army Maj. Gen. Chris Donahue, deputy director of the U.S. military's Center for International Communication, he lays out some of the issues and challenges that American forces will face during their operations in Pakistan.Among these, Donahue lays out the need for U.S. forces to train Afghan forces to fight off the Taliban insurgency and to provide a military solution that includes economic development as an option for the Afghan people. In his views, the Taliban is not a nation. Instead, he believes that what Pakistan needs is the creation of a stable, democratic, and prosperous nation."We will use the same strategy we have used in South Africa. [It is] to promote stability, to assist the people in Afghanistan, and to have a stable and peaceful region. It will not be about 'taking out' the Taliban, but it will be about'making Pakistan work, make Pakistan a better nation and a safer nation.' And that's what we will be doing," Donahue says in the video.It will not be about "taking out" the Taliban, but it will be about "making Pakistan work, make Pakistan a better nation and a safer nation," he added.Earlier in his speech, Donahue said that Pakistan's security and economic problems stem from its foreign policy of supporting Islamist groups who don't believe in democracy and are hostile to the United States and NATO."

An official at the World Food Programme says nearly a quarter of Africa's population needs emergency food aid to save lives.Nearly 12 million people in southern Africa need emergency food aid.WFP Regional Director Ramesh Swarup says an estimated 8-10 million people are in the most acute need.He says around 8-12 million people are facing food insecurity in southern Africa, with the highest number in Madagascar.He says most of the crisis is driven by acute food shortages, and is a consequence of prolonged dry spells.Swarup says it is an emergency and it is not something that will be resolved without strong leadership from the heads of state.More than 7 million people are chronically or permanently food insecure in southern Africa, with the number expected to reach 11 million by the end of the year.Swarup says a number of agencies are stepping up response, but he says more is needed to address the crisis.He said, "We have been operating in southern Africa for over 50 years and a lot of work has been done, but that is changing and we need to be ready for what's about to come."Swarup says the next two years will be very critical for southern Africa.He says WFP will focus its resources in 2017 in South Africa and Mozambique, and work on the country's long term food security.He says the agency has a mandate to ensure food security of all people, with a vision of creating a "stable, resilient, resilient" agricultural economy that is healthy and productive.Swarup said, "What we're doing at the moment is trying to find new strategies and innovations and looking at things like climate risk and resilience in agriculture.

to End Years of Bitter DisputeA Vatican aide said Wednesday the pontiff will visit the Greek island of Lesbos on his way to Cairo on Friday, ending an acrimonious years-long feud with the island’s local council over the number of migrants it should allow to stay.Migrants have long complained of harassment and discrimination in Lesbos, and locals have protested at the pontiff’s presence there for several years, saying he has no right to interfere in local issues that affect people living there.But now Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni said the pope “will take advantage of the good weather and the lack of tourists” on the island and “explore the situation” in the face of the “difficult challenges facing” those living in Lesbos and “bring about a more pastoral approach.”Bruni didn’t give details about the pope’s “colloquium” with the islanders but said that they will “have an opportunity” to “share their concerns” with the pope.The islands’ government on Wednesday issued a decree approving a resolution that allows 3,000 migrants to stay there, but only if they are in fact migrants seeking asylum and are in accordance with the law, not because they have entered in search of something better elsewhere.Lesbos’ city hall is appealing a 2016 ruling that said the island council had acted improperly by insisting on the migrants staying, but the European Court of Human Rights and several other international courts and human rights bodies have said Lesbos had a legitimate argument for the number of migrants it should accept.The island of 28,000 is the last in a group of five Greek islands along the Turkish coast, and some 20,000 people live there.Most of them are Syrian refugees who arrived on nearby Turkey’s Aegean Sea island of İzmir after the start of the Syrian civil war in 2011, and many more are asylum seekers who entered illegally from Greece.The new decree will allow three of the island’s 14,500 inhabitants to request residency documents such as work permits, but that doesn’t mean a migrant can apply to live permanently on the island because they would have to pass tests to prove they’d be able to support themselves.

Oklahoma’s oldest and first public astronaut ever, William Haynes, has recently published an article in the Kansas City Star titled "Photographing a Corn Maze in the Air: William Haynes, an Oldest and First American."William Haynes’ story dates back to 1884. It was his first year in the U.S. Navy in the Panama Canal Zone. That year, he witnessed the first moon landing and captured the first photos ever taken of Earth from orbit.William Haynes is the only American astronaut to have had a photo and a film of the moon. It's also the only photo or film ever of the Earth from space.In 2010, Haynes became the first American to walk on the Moon in the Apollo 11 Command Module.

A lawyer said Tuesday that an independent journalist who works for an online news outlet in Georgia has been kidnapped by unknown parties.Nashville, Tennessee, attorney William McRaven released a statement that said an independent investigative reporter with The Associated Press (AP) was abducted Tuesday, along with his wife, by unknown men.McRaven said the journalist was found unharmed Wednesday morning by an AP reporter.McRaven noted that the AP "applies its highest journalistic standards to all its reporters." He didn't specify how he knew the journalist had been kidnapped.The journalist's colleagues at the AP, including the AP's executive editor, declined to comment on the story."The AP strives to provide quality journalism, and we stand by that commitment," AP spokeswoman Julie Pace said. "We've been closely monitoring the AP newsroom and this story, and are working to provide more details as soon as we have them."McRaven said he had spoken to the journalist and his wife and that they told him they were unharmed. He didn't elaborate on any of their descriptions, but he thanked reporters who provided updates about the kidnapping.McRaven said he didn't know the circumstances of the abduction, but he said "the AP is a trusted news organization that is fully committed to providing its citizens with accurate and useful information."Georgia's WXIA-TV reports that police in Clark County in the Atlanta area searched an apartment complex for the man believed to be behind the abduction. Police say two people are being questioned. No arrests have been made.

After Nearly 10 Years Without A Form of GovernmentMozambique’s president, Filipe Nyusi, who has already been in office for nearly 10 years, said he wanted a new government before November, to help fight the jihadist attacks that have rocked the north since 2011.As Mozambique continues to battle the attacks of ISIS-supported groups, it must prepare for elections in 2018, and is not only going to win the battle, but will also use the new elections to set up new governing institutions and develop political and governance structures.Mozambique has long been ruled under a hybrid form of government, alternating between multiparty and single-party systems. The elections have been regularly delayed, and have been postponed three times since the beginning of the jihadist attacks of 2011 in the south.Mozambique is in a state of turmoil, with more than 1,000 dead, hundreds of thousands displaced, and an uncertain future for the country.

In the early days of Donald Trump's business life, he was mostly a real estate developer, with his real estate projects operating mostly in countries like Canada and Switzerland. But then he decided to use his connections as a real estate developer to help him get into politics with a "Trump Organization" and to build a presidential campaign that is currently embroiled in controversy.There are, of course, some caveats to this whole situation. Trump may not be as wealthy as he claims, and he has been accused of conflicts of interest with his business empire. But it's hard to deny that he's successfully built his brand around the idea of a Trump in the White House and a Trump presidency.Ivanka Trump has always been the president's daughter-in-law, but she has found her place in the White House not merely through serving as a political pawn, but by building the Trump brand and creating the political and financial benefits her family and business has found.While Trump is no longer in the public eye, the Trump family's business has remained in business and continues to grow.While the Trump family's business is still doing well, it has managed to avoid scandals like those involving her father, who was accused of mistreating women, or her brother, who was accused of taking money from foreign governments without their permission. This is largely thanks to the Trump brand, which is being built on the success and goodwill her family has managed to create with a loyal following."I know people think the Trump family is corrupt," Ivanka Trump said recently during a discussion about women and leadership with the Women's Business Council of New York City. "I hope they believe that because the fact is the Trump family's businesses are doing really well. They are growing, and not just in the fashion industry."The New York Times reported in November 2017 that the Trump Organization, through Ivanka Trump's brand, was making a profit of $80 million in the first four quarters of 2017. Ivanka's father Donald Trump is still in office, but his son Eric and daughter Ivanka still manage the Trump brand. Donald Trump's sister, Mary Trump, is an administrator of the Trump Foundation.But it's unlikely that the Trump family's business will ever be as profitable as the Trump brand.

to Quarter-FinalsSwitzerland's Sairaat Khan, right, holds the trophy after she defeated New Zealand's Rachael Haynes during the Women's Rugby World Cup Pool E match between New Zealand and New Zealand at International Stadium in Wellington, Sunday, Oct. 6, 2019. (AP Photo/Mark Baker)WELLINGTON, New Zealand (AP) — Defending champion Switzerland and her opponent in the women's World Cup quarterfinals, New Zealand, each scored four tries in a hard-fought 40-32 victory Sunday in a hard-fought Pool E match.The victory clinched Switzerland a spot in the World Cup semifinals.The two-time champions will face Japan, who lost to hosts England in a 29-28 semifinal victory.New Zealand coach Steve Hansen has a spotless record in the World Cup, having won all seven matches, including three in last year's semifinals. The Kiwis have reached the quarterfinals for six consecutive tournaments.It was a good day for the women's game as Australia clinched a 20-16 victory over New Zealand to advance and wrap up the Group B title with a 6-1 record.The only blemish for the Australians was when a penalty was given when a player appeared to push another player in the head but no penalties were given in a 30-minute delay.For the second straight day, Australia coach Dave Rennie chose to bench a key player for their quarterfinal in a bid to be at his best for the semifinal against the U.S.

00:30:00The Federal Emergency Management Agency is helping jurisdictions prepare for Hurricane Isabel, which is expected to hit U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and the northern Bahamas early next week."We've already been working with some of these jurisdictions," said Bush, as he visited Puerto Rico in preparation for Hurricane Isabel. "So we've been able to have some of our folks down there. We're going to be working with some of our folks down here. And we'll probably be helping a couple of them out. But just in order to get them started and prepared, we are sending our folks down."Bush is touring the island as he works to bring aid to the victims after Tropical Storm Irma slammed the island last week and killed at least one person. Bush also toured the storm-ravaged Florida Panhandle. He has visited four of the most affected areas, including the Panhandle's devastated Panama City.The latest estimate is that Hurricane Isabel will make landfall between the Virgin Islands and the northern Bahamas on Tuesday morning and could be the most powerful hurricane to ever hit the Caribbean in recent memory.Officials are preparing for the worst and are working to get supplies to hurricane victims as fast as possible.

U.S. retail sales came in well below analysts' expectations, an indication that the economic recovery has faltered.U.S. retail sales figures for September rose 1.4 percent from August, but that was weaker than analysts expected and well below the 2.2 percent increase in July.“September’s weak reading was somewhat less surprising than most of the forecasts that had been made for the quarter, but is not a sign that momentum has waned yet,” said Lindsey Bell, chief investment officer for Charles Schwab. “If retail sales continue to trend down like this, it could threaten the expansion and possibly send the economy down its very dangerous and unexpected curve.”Retail sales accounts for around 70 percent of the economy.Consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in six months in October.While consumer spending fell last month, the weak result was a reflection of the slowdown in the housing sector, which is leading the economy.“As the housing market continues to cool, it's likely that consumer confidence will continue to weaken. If consumer confidence stays this weak, it would be difficult for the economy to rebound,” said Paul Dales, senior economist at Capital Economics.Consumers have been the main engine of economic growth so far this year. The weak retail sales come on the heels of a disappointing consumer spending reading last week. Analysts expected consumer spending to rise a mere 0.1 percent in October.U.S. stocks declined on Monday in reaction to the disappointing retail sales numbers, while bonds were trading with some upside momentum as the market digested the data. The stock market is down by roughly 1 percent over the last several days as investors fretted that economic growth will slow further without another financial stimulus effort.Retail sales can be a reliable indicator of consumer spending but are a lagging indicator because it doesn't always happen in the same month. The Federal Reserve will be looking closely at consumer spending figures when it meets on Dec. 14-15 to make an interest rate decision. The Fed has pledged to keep interest rates low to support the U.S. economic recovery.

, Likely to Make LandfallA weak tropical storm called Arlene is expected to hit the northern Caribbean islands of Belize, Guatemala and Honduras on Monday before moving onto Central America late on Monday.Arlene was downgraded to a tropical storm on Sunday but was still expected to bring strong winds, heavy rainfall and gusts of up to 75 mph (120 kph) to some areas.The U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Sunday that the storm was a "modest disturbance in the Eastern Caribbean Sea that has a 20 percent chance of becoming a tropical depression in the next five days."It warned of "potential for life-threatening flash flooding and landslides throughout the region. Significant damage is possible to agricultural and residential sites."

Former Somali president Yusuf Dhebe, who presided over the post-Gadhafi political transformation, has died at the age of 77.Mr Dhebe suffered from a stroke on Tuesday and died on Thursday, according to friends and relatives.Mr Dhebe, who won an electoral victory in 1986 and served as president from 1989 to 1991, is best known as the person who spearheaded the transition to the nation's democratic system.In 2008, he was named Time magazine's People of the Year and that same year was awarded the Order of the Black Sea.Mr Dhebe's tenure was marked by a successful election, which was hailed as a model for the entire African continent.It was also marked by unrest, with a number of ethnic and religious clashes.Mr Dhebe was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2014 for his efforts in ensuring peace and stability in Somalia.However, the country went to the polls again in 2016 for a new presidential election, which Mr Dhebe himself was barred from taking part in, after he had been found guilty of war crimes under UN Security Council resolution 1325.

in GombeAt least two people were killed in fighting between troops from the Nigeria Army and Boko Haram insurgents at a wedding in Gombe, according to security sources.According to a Reuters report, two people died in the shooting from a Boko Haram attack on a wedding party in Gombe on Saturday.The wedding party was attacked by Boko Haram insurgents shortly before 4 a.m. on Saturday, when a group of Boko Haram militants entered a large residential complex and started firing indiscriminately, eyewitnesses told Reuters.They were not sure if civilians were targeted by the insurgents, but it is widely believed the militants attacked the wedding party because it was a gathering of Western-educated people.This would be the latest attempt to target a wedding party in the northeast of Nigeria, a decade after Boko Haram insurgents attacked a wedding party in Dapchi, the capital of Yobe state. The Boko Haram insurgency in the northeast had claimed more than 30,000 lives since 2009.

With the spread of the bird flu in southern and southeast Asia, the authorities have been scrambling to fight the spread of the virus that causes the illness.In Thailand, the number of cases has risen to about 250 and the authorities have started to vaccinate the people. In the Philippines, the flu death toll has doubled with deaths recorded in every province.Experts warn against over-battling the virus since it is still not known to be fully understood, causing a lot of fear among the public.Meanwhile, other countries across the region have stepped up their efforts to fight the virus.Meanwhile, South Korea is seeing a sharp rise in infections from the new strain of bird flu. On Wednesday, health authorities in the country confirmed that the flu has spread to the rest of the country.The country's Health Ministry said that the new strain of the virus has already reached at least 35 people in a city of more than 500,000.Health officials say that so far they have only found the virus in samples from one man.South Korean officials warn the public to maintain preventive measures, including maintaining an extra distance from people who show symptoms of bird flu, avoid close contact with wild birds and disinfect all contact surfaces after visiting wild bird areas.Meanwhile, Thailand's Agriculture Ministry announced it would deploy 150 million baht to support the country's farms affected by the outbreak of bird flu.However, the move did not go over well with some, as residents were already experiencing the effects of the disease.

On Tuesday, the United States Supreme Court said that when police use GPS tracking technology, they must get a warrant to view the data.Lawyers had challenged a decision from U.S. Magistrate Judge David Nye in Washington, D.C., who had issued a warrant in September 2017 to access a cellphone's location history to determine if it had been used at a crime scene.Police had asked to access the data for a separate, unrelated case, to determine whether the suspect had violated a restraining order issued in January 2017 against the suspect’s boyfriend.The technology used to track cellphones’ location is widely available and inexpensive, and the case was seen as a bellwether for the Fourth Amendment, the right to be searched and held harmless from unreasonable search and seizure.In the majority opinion, Justice Samuel Alito wrote, “As a general matter, warrantless access to the location data of mobile phones does not violate the Fourth Amendment.”He was joined by Justices Neil Gorsuch, Brett Kavanaugh, and Clarence Thomas.

on ThursdayOn Thursday, the House of Representatives will hold the next installment of the impeachment of South African President Jacob Zuma. This time around, the lawmakers will be debating whether or not they should call for a second set of hearings in light of several newly revealed evidence.On January 18, the House of Representatives voted to support President Zuma's bid to get immunity from prosecution through a deal with the Department of Justice. On January 23, the National Prosecuting Authority presented several additional charges in relation to corruption against the president as well as his former deputy, Mcebisi Jonas. However, even after several new investigations into allegations of corruption against President Zuma, the president still maintained that he would be cleared of any wrongdoing.The debate on whether to call for a second set of hearings will be held in the House of Representatives on Thursday.

Attempt in YemenA wanted wanted poster posted by Interpol has been released in a bid to locate and bring him to justice.The Egyptian-based organisation posted the poster on social media on Thursday, asking the public to seek him out in an attempt to capture and bring him to justice.The poster reads: "On Tuesday, a terrorist group named Islamic State (IS) attempted to kill some foreigners, including Egyptian Copts and Jews. For more information, please contact Interpol's Arabic Service or send a report to our website (info@interpol.com)."The group also urged the media to "cover the incident" and posted the picture of the wanted poster.It's not the first time that Hamas have attempted to send operatives across the world to carry out attacks, with some succumbing to the terrorist group's brutal tactics on their behalf.In 2010, Hamas operatives captured and killed Osama Abu Khattab, a Palestinian leader, in a joint raid with the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, the Islamic Movement in Judea and Samaria (Ismailiya) or the Palestinian Islamic Resistance Movement.Khattab, an al-Qaeda-linked leader, had been accused of being the mastermind of the terrorist attacks carried out against Israel last year.At the time, Ismailiya claimed that Khattab had taken over the responsibility of carrying out attacks against Jews after the assassination of Hamas' top commander Sami al-Hajaj, the group's deputy-secretary.Khattab's murder came after the assassination of Hamas spokesperson Osama Abu-Jihad al-Khatib, another al-Qaeda-affiliated militant, who also had close connections to Al-Qaeda.Hamas' efforts to send assassins across the world have been met with little success.

The French far right has uncovered some potentially damning information on their Russian financiers. The revelations are the result of a recent investigation conducted by the leader of the National Front, Marine Le Pen, as well as her party’s chief spokesman.The alleged ruse was to expose a shadowy network of financiers from the so-called “Calais camp” in France.

Pakistan's President Asif Ali Zardari said on Tuesday that Pakistan will not stop fighting the Afghan Taliban and other militants until they are eliminated from the region.Speaking in a visit to Islamabad, the Pakistani leader said that his country will give its "full might" to the struggle against Taliban and other militants in Pakistan."Pakistan is committed to bringing peace in Afghanistan and is committed to fighting against terrorism," said the president."We will give our full might to this fight," he said adding that "the world is with Pakistan in this fight and it is Pakistan's fight. We will not stop fighting until we have eradicated Taliban and other militants," he vowed.Talking to Pakistani students, the president said that they will become leaders of the world and are destined to become the most powerful world powers of the 21st century."These youths should learn from their mistakes of the past and work on improving the society," he said.The president said that education would lead to the development of Pakistan, adding that Pakistan had already done well in improving the standard of the youth.

Tigrai athletes won 11 titles in the National Taekwondo tournament organized by the Sports Authority of Pakistan.Tia-tia won the gold medal in the women’s 69kg division and Khaqan was awarded silver medal in the 69kg Division. In the Men’s 69kg Division, Mubeen bagged the silver medal.In the Men’s 69kg Division, Tia-tia was awarded the silver medal while Mubeen bagged the bronze medal. In the Men’s 85kg Division, Mujtaba won the silver medal. In the Men’s 85kg division, Mubeen bagged the bronze medal.

Venezuela’s chief prosecutor is seeking legal action against top Supreme Court justices for their actions during the government’s brutal crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.Venezuela’s Chief Prosecutor Tarek William Saab on Friday filed a complaint with the Supreme Court’s disciplinary commission accusing several of its members of usurpation of power, defamation, disobedience to their oath, the constitution and treason.“As Prosecutor of the Venezuela’s Law and order of the Judiciary I demand and declare from this platform and in the presence of these justices that you must immediately suspend and suspend until the conclusion of this prosecution the operation carried out on August 29 and 30, 2020,” Saab said in a video posted on Facebook that included footage of protests that erupted in the country in response to the decision to cut the monthly salary of teachers to a fraction of the cost.Venezuela’s constitutional court has not ruled on Saab’s request but his action could be the start of a more dramatic conflict within the government that could prove crucial in determining the future of the oil-rich nation.The action comes as opposition members of congress have rejected a motion by a parliamentary delegation to try and impeach five opposition-friendly Supreme Court justices, most of whom had overseen harsh anti-protest laws. Some said their action was retaliation for the decision of the top court to reduce the salary of teachers by half during one of the biggest waves of anti-government protests in the country’s history.The protesters chanted the term “el hombre al que esta perdido,” or “the man who fell asleep” in reference to the five Supreme Court justices.“I want you to understand this,” Venezuelan lawyer Edgar Zambrano said in video filmed by the prosecutor. “This is not a joke. You and your fellow magistrates were complicit in the killing of two people, in the face of international support. And you are asking that the president not be given the opportunity to investigate these crimes and hold the perpetrators accountable?”

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/XN2jQm1l1e8/Thousands of protesters rallied in Taiwan's main city on Thursday in a peaceful but dramatic demonstration aimed at pressing the government of President Tsai Ing-wen over a recent crackdown on protests in China's Xinjiang province.The demonstration began with a call for Tsai's government to respond to the Chinese government's alleged abuse of Uyghur Muslims in the Xinjiang province by sending some 200,000 troops to "stabilize" the situation.China's Xinjiang region has long been the focus of Chinese concern, with Tsai saying that the rights of the Xinjiang residents were under threat. The protesters said that the use of the word "stabilize" was a sign that Tsai's government was not ready to send troops to the region."The Chinese government has deployed troops to Xinjiang and has committed ethnic cleansing," said one demonstrator. "We cannot allow Beijing to carry on unchecked in the region," said another.As the demonstration began, the crowd chanted "freedom, democracy" and "China, China, China," a reference to China's repeated claim that Taiwan is its own territory, despite the island's democratically elected government having rejected the claim in the past.The protesters were divided along party lines with about 80 percent of those in the demonstration being members of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and China's government.The CCP has repeatedly stated that Taiwan is a part of China.However, Taiwan's president has expressed her support for the autonomy of Taiwan from China, saying that while she did not support Taiwanese independence, she did support the people of the self-ruling island in the face of a Chinese invasion."Taiwan is not independent, it's merely a country under China's jurisdiction," said Tsai.

KABUL—At least five people were killed by a suicide bomber Saturday near an aid delivery facility for the people of Afghanistan.The bombing took place as trucks of food and water for the people of Afghanistan were being transferred into the town of Wola.The town is located roughly 10 kilometers (6 miles) east of the capital, Kabul.Mohibullah Shiekh, spokesman for the Ministry of Public Health, said five bodies were recovered and 14 people injured in the blast.The spokesman also said a number of wounded people were taken to the hospital in the town."They are in critical condition," the spokesman said, adding that some people have died.The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
