WASHINGTON — A U.S.-backed militia in Syria conceded to journalists on Monday that they could not yet defeat the Islamic State group (IS) in that country despite more than 500 airstrikes by American-led troops."It is difficult for us to achieve security in the region, but it's also important for us to be honest and open with the public and be able to say we have difficulties and that it could take some time before we succeed in our goal of security," Abu Mohammed, a spokesman for the U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), told reporters.SDF is a coalition of local and foreign fighters who have joined the U.S.-led coalition to fight IS in Iraq and Syria. The U.S.-backed alliance has been in the country longer than the Islamic State group has been in its self-proclaimed caliphate."The ISK (IS) are a real challenge, but we are fighting them and they are not in all areas, and we are still working on it," Abu Mohammed said.ISK stands for Islamic State Khorasani, which the group's most recent leadership claimed as its official name.The group's militants have continued to carry out suicide attacks in parts of the country, including attacks in the Syrian cities of Hasakeh and Daraa in the last two weeks.U.S. airstrikes and ground forces in Syria have been largely focused on the fight against ISK.The SDF has reported losing between 50 and 100 U.S. soldiers killed in Iraq since the U.S.-led coalition declared victory in the country last November.

as One of Their Own, Report SaysIn an attempt to explain the growing popularity of Rwanda on the continent, the U.S. has been holding a series of events in the country. For example, a bipartisan group of politicians met with Kagame when they visited Rwanda in April 2015 and asked him to explain his government's policies and programs."In every country, there are people who take their place," Kagame told the gathering, referring to himself and his Rwanda National Assembly members. "We need to understand the role of government and where it has a particular responsibility, such as the role of education, or to promote economic development in a country; we need to understand the role of agriculture."While they were on the ground, politicians were repeatedly told to "understand that the government is not a single organization."In a recent Washington Post editorial, the newspaper's editorial director described the recent meetings as "a good idea" and "a way for Kagame to explain why he's popular to American audiences."The editorial suggested that Kagame was looking to "understand his own place" as the leader of a country whose people were "being oppressed and massacred," and that Kagame was doing so "to prove that he could be trusted."The editorial also argued that the U.S. should not be quick to judge Kagame's policies and "should be patient" and that such a close working relationship with his country was not a "strategic necessity," but a "good and necessary thing."In the Post story, however, journalists noted that this relationship did not exist previously. And they also noted that the State Department's policy on Rwanda has changed dramatically in recent years.In 2014, State was so frustrated with the government's human rights abuses that it imposed economic sanctions. Then, in 2017, President Trump signed a waiver that eased some of those sanctions."There are no words to describe the American disappointment with Kagame's government," said one former U.S. official at the time. "They have done nothing but kill their own people."During that meeting in April of that year, some U.S. lawmakers also criticized Kagame's human rights policies. However, Kagame has faced few international challenges since taking power in 1994, and his government has never had serious trouble in accessing foreign investment."

, China SaysThe earthquake that hit China's south-central region on Saturday killed at least 18 people, China said, a magnitude 6.4 quake that jolted some residents of the region in a region that had previously seen three deadly quakes.China said the latest quake had caused at least 18 deaths, but it gave no specific figures, with a toll expected to climb when search and rescue efforts resumed.The quake struck early on Saturday morning, the China Earthquake Administration said.It struck the area around Huaihai City in the Hubei province, with at least some damage to buildings there, according to the local government, which said it was not yet time for rescue.There was no immediate reports of major injuries or major damage in the quake-hit region.China has been hit by a number of deadly quakes over the past couple years.

Thousands of bodies have been discovered in mass graves close to the battlefront against Islamic State, according to local activists and residents.Bodies of both women and men were discovered in separate mass graves close to one of the towns liberated by government forces in July of 2016 from the militant group, a resident in Idlib province told RFE/RL.Idlib province, as well as other parts of Syria and the Russian-Turkish de-escalation zone in the country's south, are home to multiple Islamic State (IS) sleeper cells.Syrian state media said that "at least 600" people have died in the Idlib province, but the resident of Idlib province denied that figure."We've learned from our security forces that thousands of bodies have been found there," said Hayat Al-Sham, a local militia group which was also active in the battle against IS.In July 2016, IS fighters set about burning villages close to the Turkish border in Idlib province."

, Security in AfghanistanThe United Nations on Monday warned that human rights are essential to peace and security in Afghanistan, despite the ongoing violence.The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said that "despite the ongoing conflict, the human rights of the civilian population are a priority" for the country, and that the international community's continued engagement is needed to help."Despite the continued conflict, the human rights of the civilian population are a priority for Afghanistan. The protection and protection of civilians is especially important in light of the continuing conflict, ongoing human rights violations, and the threat of further violence," the OCHA added."Human rights are also essential in facilitating the safe, voluntary and dignified repatriation of Afghan nationals and other foreigners stranded in the country. The safe, voluntary, dignified, return of Afghan nationals and other foreigners, including women and children, is one of the key tasks to be done," the UN added.Despite the ongoing conflict and threats from further violence, the humanitarian community has made great strides in providing humanitarian assistance to the country, UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore told the annual G7 summit."Human rights are the basis of our global stability. They are essential to international security. And we can never give up these values, whether it is the right to a decent education, safe and affordable water supply, or the right to life," she stressed in her opening remarks, according to a UN News Service report.Fore also stressed that "all efforts to strengthen national institutions to tackle root causes of conflict and to enable a lasting reduction of violence" are absolutely essential."This means prioritising peace and reconciliation, development, development finance, education, human rights and gender equality, climate change, and sustainable development," Fore said."As a result, Afghanistan is now among the countries where the greatest growth in the last 15 years has come from," said Fore.The latest UN figures show that in 2015, the United Nations distributed $9.8 billion in humanitarian assistance and delivered $6.3 billion of it, and another $8.2 billion were collected.The UN also said that in the same year, it delivered $1 billion in emergency medical supplies and delivered more than 4 million tons of relief material, including 2.4 million tons of rice, 8.4 million blankets, 2 million masks and 2 million vaccines.

SurgeWith a record number of COVID-19 cases in the United States topping 23 million, hospitals in many states are struggling to prepare for an onslaught of patients. The World Health Organization recently warned of a “dark winter” as hospitals prepare to handle record patient numbers.In Michigan, a record number of people are being hospitalized with COVID-19 in the state.“The people who are dying today are the people who will live in the worst possible fashion in the future,” said Dr. David F. Zucker, the medical director for the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.The rise in cases has forced many hospitals to switch from normal COVID-19 treatments to using intensive care units (ICUs) to manage non-COVID patients, placing them in the same rooms as coronavirus patients.On Wednesday, the number of patients in Michigan’s ICUs surpassed 2,000, a number not seen since mid-April.“We have never seen the type of demand on ICUs we are seeing now,” said William J. Hines, the president of Johns Hopkins University, where COVID-19 cases have surpassed 8 million.In some places, medical staff and staff members have had to work longer and longer hours, to keep up with the demand.“We are seeing things that we have never seen before,” said Dr. Howard S. Graff, the medical director at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.Graff also pointed out that some ICUs have had to send patients home to care for their sick relatives because they couldn’t manage their COVID-19 patients in their own homes.This week, one hospital director in Michigan had to tell patients in their final days that they were losing their beds.“We have to make some hard decisions to try to make sure that we don't reach a point where our resources are no longer available,” said Thomas E. Ricks, the president and CEO of Beaumont Hospital, in Michigan.In New Jersey, hospital directors have warned that it will be an “unprecedented” problem if they are faced with an increase of COVID-19 cases.In New York, where COVID-19 has claimed some 28,000 lives, New Jersey Gov.

The Islamic State (ISIL) in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) claimed responsibility for a car bombing near the headquarters of a rebel group in Syria’s northern city of Raqqa, killing 10 civilians and wounding 20 more, according to a statement released Thursday.The bombing occurred early Thursday in the Syrian city where the jihadist group is based. The al-Rai hospital in Raqqa confirmed that 10 people were killed in the explosion.The blast occurred near a house belonging to an al-Jabha military faction, al-Hayyat al-Islam (Ahrar al-Sham). The wounded have been taken to a nearby medical center, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.A Syrian source told Sputnik that another 10 people were injured. The source added that the blast targeted an ambulance of Ahrar al-Sham’s military wing, as well as a vehicle of another rebel group, Nusra Front.The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported 10 people killed in the bombing.The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) claimed responsibility for a car bombing near the headquarters of a rebel group in Syria’s northern city of Raqqa, killing 10 civilians and wounding 20 more, according to a statement released Thursday.The bombing occurred early Thursday in the Syrian city where the jihadist group is based.

(Image: AFP/Getty)The new populist, illiberal Europe is beginning to resemble the US and Western Europe of the 1930s, but without the economic and political stability. Europe’s leaders may finally be listening.The rise of “populist movements” – far-right parties, nationalists, nationalists, and some liberal conservatives – across Europe in recent years has been alarming to European leaders. Some of them fear they are moving toward illiberalism and may become more difficult to control.The new populist, illiberal Europe is beginning to resemble the US and Western Europe of the 1930s, but without the economic and political stability. Europe’s leaders may finally be listening.One of the key elements of illiberalism is the use of the legal system to prevent people from exercising democracy. It may be seen as the new tyranny of the masses. In the United States during the 1920s, popular movements like the League of Labor forced the government to provide better civil rights, and helped turn the nation from a conservative to a progressive nation. It is often thought that the Great Depression was caused by the excesses of the New Deal. In Europe, illiberal governments were able to take advantage of the economic dislocation of the Great Depression to prevent political debate on important issues.In the last three years, Europe’s populist and illiberal movements have moved beyond the traditional boundaries of traditional political alliances. Now they are challenging not only the traditional parties but also the political institutions of the European Union.For example, European leaders reacted furiously to a recent report from French President Emmanuel Macron, who made a speech to an audience of the European Parliament denouncing racism and anti-Semitism in Europe. Macron, a former investment banker, is making an attempt to rebrand the movement’s aims by portraying himself as a champion of liberal values. He is right: his report found that many of Europe’s anti-immigrant parties were led by individuals with questionable or even dubious backgrounds and many of them shared little if any of Europe’s liberal values.

Marlene Kitzhaber: We’re on the cusp of another big-picture housing policy policyOn the cusp of a housing policy.The president and his wife have not missed a chance to announce a policy — often a big one — during his tenure in office.In May 2016, at the urging of the White House and its think tank, we launched a national housing policy survey for households to make recommendations for the president on how to improve housing for everyone in our country.We included housing as a "big issue" in the survey, along with education, the state of our infrastructure, the environment, and the state of the economy.

The United States is seeking diplomatic dialogue with China, including seeking Beijing's consent for an intelligence-sharing alliance with Thailand, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman said on Tuesday in Bangkok, a day after Chinese military announced that it was sending a ballistic missile to the Spratly Islands.Sherman said the U.S. had proposed the dialogue to China. "We think it is important for all countries to come together when they face a threat," she told reporters during a press conference, calling for dialogue to be reciprocal. "We want to be able to share intelligence without any preconditions."The deputy secretary said it was a good time to bring the dispute to the negotiating table. "You can't solve things without having dialogue," she said.The U.S. deputy secretary said the U.S. and China have been conducting naval drills this month and warned the United Kingdom about any Chinese activity in the Indian Ocean. She said she spoke on the phone with British Foreign Secretary William Hague the same day.She expressed the hope that Britain would not take the U.S.'s statement as a threat and could maintain its commitment to a bilateral agreement with Taiwan."The British have been an important partner in our effort, to bring about a peaceful resolution in the Taiwan issue," she said. "We remain hopeful that Britain will remain steadfast on its commitment to Taiwan, just as they have on their commitment to the international system."Sherman had earlier visited China's embassy in Thailand. She has also met Thai PM Yingluck Shinawatra during her visit to the U.S.

NEW DELHI (AP) — In the first case confirmed in the Indian subcontinent in more than a year, the World Health Organization declared Friday that Bhutan and the Maldives had eliminated measles.It was Bhutan’s first case of measles since January 2020 when a child was infected in a tourist resort on the Himalayan kingdom’s southwestern coast.WHO said Bhutan’s vaccination rates in the last decade are among the best in the world and it is now ready to host large numbers of visitors.Bhutan, a Buddhist country of around 30 million people, has vaccinated more than 85% of its people, WHO’s head of immunization for the region, Mary Morrey, said during an online briefing Friday.The Maldives declared that it too was free of measles with fewer than 10 confirmed cases as of 2019.With more than 100 million citizens, India is India’s largest single immunization program, with more than 2 million health workers delivering more than a million shots per day.The country has more than 1.3 billion people, more than any other country.Measles is one of three major infectious diseases that can be transmitted through contact.A weakened or inactive virus is still infecting a vulnerable person, but because symptoms only manifest themselves when enough time has passed since the last case of infection, these people don’t have any apparent symptoms.Bhutan’s isolation and rapid response systems allowed it to quickly detect this case and quickly respond, Morrey said. The country did not report any new cases in 2020.“The country has performed extremely well over the last 10 years,” said Dr. Dileep Nangula, WHO’s assistant director-general for immunization.The Maldives, in the Indian Ocean, began vaccinating its people in 2017, but the number of confirmed cases has fallen sharply as a result of a “concerted national immunization campaign.”

(CN) – The Environmental Protection Agency must bolster its oversight of water supplies under the 2010 National Water Supply Improvements Act, the Government Accountability Office has found.In a letter to EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, the watchdog agency’s Office of Inspector General said that the National Water Supply Improvements Act did not require the EPA to ensure that water supplies are safe before the National Water Supply Reform Act took effect."Specifically, the National Water Supply Improvement Act did not require the EPA to ensure that water supplies were safe before water sources and drinking water systems were restored," the IG’s report said.The IG’s office said the National Water Supply Reform Act, as it was initially enacted, did not impose penalties for water quality issues that led to contaminated water."However, under a revised National Water Supply Reform Act, the EPA must identify and correct any water sources for which water quality is impacted and address compliance issues that result in those water sources being withdrawn for a period of time," the report said."

The EU reported on Tuesday that it was conducting a "credible investigation" into two Georgia and Russia incursions into the Black Sea and the Sea of Azov during a five-day conflict in March 2019.Georgia is fighting for its sovereignty to be respected, which is why it is demanding a return to Tbilisi's control of the Sea of Azov during the incident. Russia has accused Tbilisi of being behind the Black Sea incidents.The EU, which has a wide network of political and military officers across Europe, said that in 2019 it had "conducted extensive and credible investigations" into five incidents involving Russia, the Black Sea Sea and the Sea of Azov.The European Union on Tuesday called for a "transparent and inclusive" investigation into a five-day Russian-Georgia conflict in March 2019.The conflict involved Russian forces backing Georgia against a pro-Moscow separatist force in Georgia's breakaway South Ossetia region.After the five-day conflict ended, the EU conducted a number of probes into what happened during the incidents.The EU's chief spokesperson, Michael Pintree, said Tuesday the EU conducted a "credible investigation" into the events as they happened in 2019.He called for "a transparent and inclusive" investigation into events after the conflict, after Russia accused the EU of political bias in the matter.He added that the EU would ask Russia to cooperate with it and cooperate with the probe, which was based on "reliable" intelligence, reports AFP.In the March 4-5 incident, the EU also found Russian troops and artillery units entering the Sea of Azov.In another incident, Russia blamed a U.S.-supplied surveillance system for allegedly giving the "green light" for a Russian attack."

HARARE, Zimbabwe — After four days of crippling strikes and protests over low wages, Zimbabwe's president on Saturday again warned his country's doctors against calling another day of work.HARARE, Zimbabwe — After four days of crippling strikes and protests over low wages, Zimbabwe's president on Saturday again warned his country's doctors against calling another day of work.The president's ultimatum came after a day of more than 100 doctors and nurses striking for better pay at one of the country's largest state hospitals. The doctors say their pay is too low.The president's warning followed a government decision to impose a nationwide lockdown that began on Friday to curb the spread of the coronavirus."No one is in a better position to judge your attitude in terms of being able to fight the corona crisis than the president himself," said Robert Mugabe, who heads Zimbabwe's ruling party.The government imposed the lockdown after more than 300 people attended a private funeral — one of several events that have been linked to the coronavirus — at a mosque in Harare's affluent Mvura suburb.The government ordered people attending funerals to wear masks and to be confined to their homes for 14 days following the funeral.On Saturday, more than 100 doctors and nurses who had staged strikes for better pay staged another protest at one of Zimbabwe's largest state hospitals in Harare's capital, demanding better working conditions and their salaries should be increased to $100 ($0.01 per hour), which they say is below the poverty line."The current pay levels at some state hospitals are insufficient to care for our patients," said doctor James Sanyang. "It is in this regard that we would like to express our strong displeasure in the face of the employer."

byThe leaders of Britain, France and Germany say they are putting aside political differences and agree to find common ground when it comes to economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.European Union leaders called in a video conference to discuss cooperation and recovery from the crisis, but didn't provide details on what they will agree on next.Britain and France agreed last week to offer support to the EU in exchange for more access to markets."We have overcome the greatest crisis in our history and I can tell you that today we stand on the brink of a better future for Europe," said French President Emmanuel Macron at the start of the meeting.Macron was followed by German Chancellor Angela Merkel who also praised "our solidarity" and urged leaders "to strengthen it more" in the face of the economic crisis.Merkel also urged a "bold but fair" plan that would be "in keeping" with European values of democratic values, free markets and free societies.A joint communique from the leaders will be issued later Monday.The leaders praised the "solidarity" and "solidarity in action" that has been displayed throughout the crisis in the bloc. They also spoke about the "responsibility" to strengthen cohesion through measures like joint recovery plans for the EU's 27 member states."We can and should take up the task of ensuring a swift and successful vaccination, that we must take together," Merkel said.Macron told his European counterparts he wanted a "Europe of hope" after the crisis."We know that the next steps are going to be in our hands and we will have to fight the next battle on the same footing," he said.The leaders also discussed the digital transition in the "ever-changing and interconnected world.""

, and Offer Gift of Ties for DonorsIn a new partnership with a local bank, the French capital’s Basilica of Saint-Laurent will be among the first in France to take contactless payments using mobile phones, in a bid to attract donations.A series of small plastic objects dubbed ‘tickets’, are being installed around the Basilica. They will have to be used once to register, and be given to any person who wants to take them, according to the site, in exchange for money.The basilica’s website said: “The first payment is given to the individual who takes the ticket and gives it to the first person to come and take it. A further payment is made at a later time when the same ticket is taken by another person.”The bank is offering a series of tie designs that can be given to the donors to mark their support.The website explained: “The Basilica is seeking donations, either in the form of cash, goods, or services. It is not expected to be able to collect money for the projects.”Basilica officials said that donations would also be accepted at the door of the basilica, and that all donations would be used for the various parish projects.According to the basilica, the idea is that the new cards will be used as a “paperless” channel, allowing donors to easily transfer funds from their bank accounts to the church’s coffers.The basilica will take the cards from their respective banks.The cards will have a QR code and a unique identification number which will be sent to the bank.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina — Argentine authorities carried out raids at the homes of fugitive businessman Carlos Alberto Fernandez, his former secretary of his ruling party, on Thursday.Fernandez, who also served as head of state during the country's 1980-1984 armed confrontation with leftist rebels, has been on the run since he fled his home in Buenos Aires in January 2019."Argentine police executed a warrant issued by a magistrate, and seized property in Boca Junctions," the official Twitter account of Interior Minister Ricardo Alarcon said. "The authorities are looking for weapons."Alarcon later posted a photo of himself on Twitter with Fernandez.Fernandez's former secretary of state, Julio De Vido, said in a tweet that the "arrest warrant was served for his arrest."Fernandez is the architect of the social program that was the political cornerstone of President Alberto Fernández's government during the 1980s — but which has become a bone of contention between the two men.Fernandez was forced from power in 1986 after the military coup that ended Argentina's 27-year rule.The economy is now doing better under Fernández than it did when he took office, but the political system is divided on his "Fernandezism," and he now faces another test as he faces opposition from the same groups who drove him out of power during the civil war.

Published on 26 February 2017 | Author:Katharine E.The latest tragic incident in China involving a mine at Huangxing in Jilin province is a call to action. In its wake are proposals for mine rescue and an improvement in mine clearance practices in the wake of the recent tragedy.The mine explosion in Huangxing's Huangshi Village killed 26 people. The mine was operated by a local mine contractor and it occurred after the contractor failed to secure the mine. This tragedy occurred at a time when there was a national focus on the safety of mines and the mines industry.

in Iowa×  in IowaDES MOINES, Iowa (AP) — A federal judge in Texas blocked U.S. officials from erecting a fence that would separate a swath of Iowa from its largest city.The ruling, issued Tuesday, temporarily bars work on a section of wall in southeast Texas planned under a new law that President Donald Trump is calling his “toughest” at the southern border.Trump’s action was seen as part of a broader effort to shift more of the billions in federal funds available for construction of a wall along the Mexican border to the states, an action that Trump has used to build some of his signature projects since he took office.The ruling from U.S. District Judge Sam Moulton in Corpus Christi is the second temporary nationwide injunction handed down by the judge in the case. On Tuesday, he issued a temporary nationwide stay on work on the Rio Grande Valley of Texas after a similar ruling in Arizona.Texas and Arizona argued that they needed the wall to protect against crime and drug smuggling.The judge said in his ruling that he did not think his order would result in the border being “virtually empty,” a conclusion that was contested by Texas officials.Moulton said he had to weigh whether he could keep the wall in place for the time being while the government appeals the case. It’s possible that the next hearing in the case will not be held in his courtroom.Moulton said he was concerned that parts of the wall would be built to look more like posts and less like the concrete sections of fencing that have been in place in places along the Mexican border.In April, Moulton ordered that parts of a border fence in eastern New Mexico must be taken down and that a new type of mesh barrier — one made of steel — be used. In his ruling Tuesday, Moulton stopped short of ordering the entire fence, but he noted that it could include some parts of it.Trump has pledged to construct 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) of wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and to build new sections where existing walls fall short. Moulton’s decision makes it possible that some of the construction will be done in Texas, where new barriers are not permitted.

Hurricane Florence has been downgraded to a tropical storm, but it's already affecting the air force and its pilots.With the storm bearing down on the Carolinas, the air force has sent six KC-130's and four KC-10's into the path of the storm to help out the military forces at sea and at home.One KC-10 is stationed at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, and four others are deployed to Naval Air Station Patuxent River in Maryland, where the KC-10s will deliver extra supplies and resupply to U.S. forces stationed in and around the Carolinas.The sixth KC-10, a KC-130J, also is stationed at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada.Another KC-10 is stationed at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada.The air force crews in all the planes are well trained to deal with emergency operations like these.The KC-10 pilots will be on standby for the hurricane in case things go really south. Their planes will also be ready to relieve otherKC-130's if the needs arise. The KC-10 and KC-135's will be used to bring in food, water, fuel, and other supplies if necessary as the hurricane advances through the North Atlantic Ocean.

For more than an hour, the candidates for the Democratic nomination in 2020 gathered at Los Angeles’ Staples Center to take part in the second presidential debate on Oct. 15. Democratic voters are likely to cast their ballot before then but, before then, have plenty of other things to consider.Here’s a look at some of the things that will come up during the debate and the things they have said about race relations, the climate and the economy, and everything in between.The first presidential debate, in June, was dominated by issues like sexual misconduct, racial injustice and white privilege.But in the last debate, the stage was expanded to include three more African American candidates: former Vice President Joe Biden; Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.); and Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.).That means that the first six of the first 14 candidates qualified for the second debate. With that amount of candidates, there will be plenty of hot topics.Here is a roundup of the most notable quotes from both the Democratic candidates and the moderator from the debate:Democratic presidential candidate Beto O’Rourke speaks onstage at a debate hosted by PBS on Oct. 15, 2019, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)The environmentHarris is the only female candidate who has been to the summit of Mount Everest, but she’s only addressed climate change in one of her campaigns: during her 2018 Senate campaign in California, she called climate change “the most important issue” facing the country and called for a Green New Deal to address its impact on communities such as the Navajo Nation in Arizona.“But just think of all the people who are going to suffer, who are going to die, who are going to be pushed into living in the streets,” Harris said last week. “What are we going to do about this?”The answer isn’t necessarily to ban fracking, but to pass laws in every state that require it to be a necessary part of the process, she said. She also said she’d support a ban on the use of the pesticide neonicotinoid.Climate change and energyThis isn’t a debate the Democratic nominee should lose, because it is the central theme of the next four years.

US Army personnel from Forward Operating Base Fingah in Afghanistan's Kunduz province take cover after a drone attack, on October 20, 2001. / AFP / Rahmatullah SayeedUS troops have shifted from a military focus on "winning" against the Taliban and al-Qaeda to a more limited approach involving strikes on al-Qaeda figures in Afghanistan, former generals say.Advertising Read moreThe strategy shift is part of a gradual shift that has begun in recent years as US troops' main goal has been ending the insurgency in Afghanistan and helping stabilize the country as a US military base comes up for renewal, they said.The shift is not as abrupt as in 2007 or 2008, when US forces were in a "search and destroy" mode, as Gen. David Petraeus put it in his 2013 memoir.During the early years, Petraeus said, the war was often "a grind," with combatant commanders trying to control the environment and maintain momentum with limited supplies.A senior US official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the US is no longer trying to win every day, but instead is trying to destroy al-Qaeda's leadership and prevent its ability to operate in the region.The shift of focus away from victory in the war and toward destroying al-Qaeda leaders began in 2018, when President Donald Trump was elected, the official said.Al-Qaeda, the former Al-Qaeda in Afghanistan (AQA) leader and the world's top al-Qaeda terrorist organization in 2011, has been struggling in Afghanistan in recent years. The Taliban, the hardline Islamist group that rules Afghanistan, has been on the defensive against the US-backed Afghan government since 2015.

Lebanon's startup community is not just a great place to set up shop, but also the perfect place to make real impact on society.It's also a place where the business-minded people with good ideas can find support, and the ones with no ideas can get support from the community.Startups have a long-standing and close relationship with startups and with the community.In fact, the most successful entrepreneurs here have often come from the community. Most notable has been the case of the Lebanese startup of Echos Digital Media.Lebanese startups have been part of social initiatives in different ways, starting with a local nonprofit that helped the poor get mobile phones for them, then with a charitable charity that provides water.While there is obviously an element of profit-making involved in some of the ideas, the idea of starting a business in a country like Lebanon involves far more than just making a quick buck.It is not surprising that some of the first and most successful entrepreneurs here come from the communities that they are trying to impact.For the new arrivals to Lebanon, and all of those already here, it can be challenging to navigate the startup world. There are many great resources to get an idea started, but the hard part is getting it funded. There are also a lot of things that you might want to know that you don’t realize you need or can’t afford to do yourself or the startup doesn’t need to pay you to do it.Lebanon, like many countries around the globe is suffering a financial crisis and is trying to fix it one piece of the puzzle at a time. In many of the developing countries, the government’s only interest is in ensuring that the companies and industries are creating the jobs that they can’t hire locally.However, in some cases, the companies have to spend more money than they would like, or the companies have to invest even more money to try to create jobs, not just the people that are employed in their businesses.

, Urges Staying CalmU.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is warning North Korea against carrying out a satellite launch.On Tuesday, a North Korean satellite reportedly blasted into the sky over the Sea of Japan.Guterres addressed the issue with his Japanese counterpart Fumio Kishida, calling on both to keep calm, according to a statement published by the U.N."I am concerned by the reports of an ICBM test that was carried out today in North Korea. I urge North Korea to refrain from taking any action that could lead to war," he said."I also urge Japan to ensure that any military action that it might take is proportionate to the threat posed by North Korea," he said, stressing that he and his Japanese counterpart are discussing the matter.Kishida echoed the secretary-general's call for restraint."In response, the United Nations is working with other countries, including Japan, to promote dialogue through diplomatic means, through a peaceful process that will lead to greater international cooperation to resolve the situation and achieve a peaceful settlement for the Korean Peninsula," he said.The United States is also urging North Korea to stop its missile and nuclear development.In a tweet on Tuesday, U.S. President Donald Trump warned China to "get involved" in the crisis as the president also made reference to the planned ICBM test.

, Despite Fears of CoronavirusThe United Nations is calling for free and fair elections in Lebanon on Feb. 14 despite the country's rising coronavirus toll and fears over the spread of the global pandemic, the UN Security Council said Thursday.Lebanon is facing its worst economic and health crisis in decades, and the country is facing a possible default on its debt."

After Trump-Putin Summithttp://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/v0V1aP7jg3M/WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed their long-festering disputes as well as steps they believe can be taken to defuse some of the tensions that flared following the long-running war in Afghanistan.Biden and Putin met in Geneva for a one-on-one session following their talks on Tuesday that focused on Afghanistan, the climate crisis and trade. They also worked out details on a potential meeting between Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin, which the two men have repeatedly expressed interest in attending next year.The leaders also discussed their respective approaches to countering cybercrime and ensuring cyber insurance coverage for critical infrastructure, while stressing the need for Russia to take "prompt steps" to end its support for ransomware attacks on American businesses.Biden, who won a presidential election last month largely based on his promise to restore America's long-standing international leadership, said Putin and his government have been "unpredictable" and warned against the potential for increased Russian interference in the 2020 U.S. elections.The two leaders, who have met once previously — in Helsinki, Finland, for the Group of Seven meeting in 2018 — also expressed an eagerness to improve their strained relationship following four years of intense U.S.-Russian relations, said senior administration officials who briefed reporters on the meeting.The Kremlin said the meeting was primarily about boosting ties but noted that Russia and the United States are facing "difficult" relations and that the leaders "may consider the possibility of holding a meeting next year to discuss all aspects of their bilateral relationship."That would mark the first time Putin and Biden have sat down face to face since Biden took office. They met virtually at the G7 summit in June.The meeting came amid a U.S.-Russia standoff over the situation in Afghanistan, the climate crisis and the war in Ukraine that has left more than 2,400 U.S. soldiers dead and nearly 20,000 wounded over the past three decades.

President Donald Trump sued the Manhattan district attorney Monday over an subpoena seeking his personal financial records, an action that could allow Democrats to question him in an impeachment trial.Trump’s lawyers said that he would challenge the subpoena issued by District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. and the city’s Comptroller Scott Stringer as well as challenge their jurisdiction over the case.“This case will also allow the president to assert his legal right to remain silent,” Trump’s lawyers said in a statement.The New York Times has reported that Trump directed his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, to attack Vance over the probe. It said that Vance asked for the financial records to “better understand” how Trump invested, and the president’s lawyers called that request a “misuse of process” that they would oppose.“The president’s efforts to obstruct this investigation should be resisted,” the lawyers added. “His efforts to interfere with this investigation are unprecedented and, if left unchecked, threaten to undermine the rule of law.”Trump is embroiled in a legal battle with two women who say he sexually assaulted them. A federal appeals court has refused to overrule a judge’s order that compelled Trump to give his tax returns to prosecutors.Trump, a Republican, has argued that the tax returns have nothing to do with the two women, one of whom says she had an affair with Trump years before the alleged assault.There is no question that Trump’s personal financial dealings are a central topic of the investigation.

ATHENS – Greece’s government on Friday defended a court decision that held back extradition to Turkey of soldiers suspected of involvement in deadly 2010 events, saying it must be respected and there is no need for a fresh court procedure.Greece’s ruling coalition and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras have been accused of seeking to have their allies acquitted in the case in order to ensure they remain in office come the next election in 2019.Greece’s chief prosecutor said on Thursday the court would not back a request by the government to send the soldiers to Turkey for trial, despite a court’s verdict last week that ruled against them.Tsipras and his government have called for new court proceedings on the basis that the men’s trial would be fair and would not be politicized ahead of a fresh general election.Tsipras said during an interview with the Kathimerini daily that any attempt to circumvent the original decision by the court would be an “adversarial procedure” and would not be accepted.He also rejected allegations that Greece was seeking to be granted legal immunity for members of his government, saying that this was “an imaginary interpretation.”The issue of whether Tsipras and his government should be tried for war crimes for allegedly ordering attacks on the Kurdish minority during the fighting against the Islamic State militant group in Syria has also plagued their governing coalition in recent months.The military actions of Greece’s foreign policy since the country’s 2011 crisis have come under fire from Turkey, an ally of the government of Greek premier Alexis Tsipras, over the alleged violations of the Geneva convention.The prosecutor has previously said that there was no “legal reason” to send the men back for prosecution.

on MondayA meeting between the Palestinian leadership and the Middle East Quartet on Monday in Lisbon will highlight an important issue for Israel – the Palestinian Authority’s refusal to halt its policies toward the Jewish people.The visit is coming at a critical juncture for Israel’s security in light of the violent riots that broke out in Jerusalem in recent days over the contested al-Aqsa Mosque, and clashes and riots throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip that followed. The Palestinian Authority (PA) maintains full control of al-Aqsa and other holy places on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, and has declared that it is the sole custodian of the al-Aqsa compound and all other al-Aqsa sites in East Jerusalem. That includes al-Aqsa itself.

Lawyers from the New Jersey based environmental group Earth Justice have lost the U.S. Supreme Court’s latest effort to block a lawsuit brought by youth activists over the failure to curb climate change.Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito and Neil Gorsuch were unavailable.The case comes just before Thanksgiving, which is often a big time for fundraising by the legal community. So it was a huge win for the plaintiffs, Earth Justice, which has been successful in other cases where they sued powerful groups to get more funding.One of the lawyers for the group, Michael Gerrard, told me in an email from Washington that he was “pleased that the Supreme Court declined to review this case”.It is hard to say what the group’s next steps will be, because that sort of thing rarely goes well for environmental causes: it is very hard to get enough people behind a case and it is also very hard to succeed in winning the U.S. Supreme Court.The New Jersey based group is already gearing up for its next Supreme Court fight. It has filed a second case, which will seek to block a coal-fired power plant from operating in New Jersey that is also seeking to go through the state’s judicial process.In case you missed it, last April, a group of about 75 youths filed a suit in the U.S.

Philanthropist Bill Gates sounds a warning on cuts to development aid.As part of a series of interviews with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Gates called on governments and civil societies around the world to help more people in the face of worsening poverty and inequality.Gates said the U.S. is the largest donor to the World Bank and the Gavi vaccine alliance, but that it could "do more." Gates made clear that while the U.S. has a more robust economy, it also has a higher rate of poverty and an increase in inequality. And he made clear that if the U.S. were not the largest donor to such organizations, other countries would be.Gates said the U.S. government, which he described as a "brutally honest" one, had a lot of room to help other countries. But at the same time, the U.S. has more poverty, a higher rate of inequality, and a larger population than many other countries."In my opinion, this is not an easy problem to solve, but I don’t think there is one single solution that would satisfy all parties," he said."I’ve never heard a single person in Washington say we have to cut development aid," he said. "I think a lot of people who are saying that are saying that because they don’t want to say that they don’t have the money."Gates cited his own experience of trying to help get his son and wife out of poverty in Africa. He said that his efforts were often rewarded with praise by Washington. But that only made the problem worse.Gates cited other factors that contributed to the poverty and inequality he sees in his current work."All these problems can be traced back to the fact that most people are concentrated in about a few places, and that those countries have relatively high poverty," he said.

Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine on March 16, 2014; this is the third time that Russia has annexed eastern Ukraine from a country (and only second time from Russia).Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine on March 16, 2014; this is the third time that Russia has annexed eastern Ukraine from a country (and only second time from Russia).This video from Novaya Gazeta, Ukraine's state-run news agency, shows the convoy of trucks heading out to the Russian border:This video from Novaya Gazeta, Ukraine's state-run news agency, shows the convoy of trucks heading out to the Russian border:As Russian security forces continued to clear land, the separatists drove in with the aid of Ukrainian military vehicles:Russia's military and military-technical aid has been an important part of the war that has raged in Eastern Ukraine between government forces and pro-Russia separatist forces.The war is far from over. The rebels have relied on the support of Russian-backed, Ukrainian army fighters, whose numbers and weaponry vary widely from place to place.
