A collection of a century's worth of possessions belonging to India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, will be auctioned off.India's Nehru House will be sold off on August 8th as the last remaining piece of a collection of property that includes the personal effects belonging to India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru.Sellers had earlier set an asking price of $8 million (about Rs 64 crore) for the house, and India's Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) agreed to that amount.The final price will likely be somewhere in the ballpark of $1.8 million, experts said.The items will be sold separately as three lots, and one lot will go for $8 million (about Rs. 64 crore) and another set will go for $1.8 million (about Rs. 64 crore) and the third set of items will go for $1 million.The items to be auctioned are the personal belongings of India's first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, with a few gifts from his wife Indira Gandhi also included in the lot.The Nehru House is located in New Delhi and is known for being a "socially, politically and economically vibrant house".Last year, the house was demolished to make way for a metro station in the Delhi Metro zone. The auction of items is said to be a prelude to a museum at the house.Some of the items that will be auctioned are Nehru's diaries and a portrait of his wife and former prime minister Indira Gandhi which were bequeathed to the Nehru House by the then British government of India, a statement from the auction house said."The Nehru House is not the only house in New Delhi. It is also the only house with a museum attached to it and an air-conditioned museum," the statement read.According to a 2015 report in a publication in India, the Nehru House was "already in the doldrums, with most of its original furnishings now in a ruinous state".

After 3.5 Million Voters Cast BallotsWASHINGTON (UrduPoint News / Sputnik - 20th January, 2020) United States elections are peaceful and secure even though millions of Americans voted for President Donald Trump, the US Electoral College has certified the results, a source familiar with the election told Sputnik on Friday.The source said that more than three-and-a-half million people voted in the US midterm elections and more than 2.5 million people voted in the US presidential elections."The transfer of power is peaceful," the source said.Elections run smoothly in the United States of America even though there are millions of Americans who want to see the outgoing president - Donald Trump - not only removed but also replaced with an alternative, the source said."The election is going smoothly. It is not up for debate that there are millions of people who want [Trump] to be removed. It is also not up for debate that the election is not secure for him, in the same way that the UK, Spain, and France elections are secure," the source said.The UK's House of Commons, for instance, voted to formally accept Brexit, while Spain's Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez won a confidence vote.The United States, on the other hand, is one of the most secure countries in the world, the source added.On Thursday, the US Electoral College confirmed the election results and the Senate also confirmed them.As a result, President-elect Joe Biden will now be inaugurated to his second four-year term. Trump will take up his post as a Cabinet member.

© AFP 2016/ Maksim Bolyazhian US Calls for 'Fairer' Settlement in South OssetiaMOSCOW (Sputnik) — "If there is no peace settlement on the peninsula, there will be an even greater crisis in the region," Trump said at a joint press conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin.The United States and Russia have been locked in a long-standing territorial dispute over South Ossetia, a region that is heavily Russian-populated. The conflict began in August 2008 when Georgian forces captured and occupied the territory. Since then, Russia has been fighting the separatists, who it considers part of the Georgian side.The United States has offered a number of solutions for peace between the sides, including a referendum on independence. The United States also has offered to mediate, but the Georgian side rejected them, saying that they would have been satisfied with a peace deal that was only a resolution to the long-standing conflict.US President Donald Trump on Tuesday urged an end to bloodshed on the peninsula."All lives are worth fighting for," Trump said, speaking at a joint press conference with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin."I want there to be peace and for peace to come, so no lives should be lost, and if lives are lost there will be an even greater crisis," Trump said, urging for the ceasefire to be implemented.In response, the Georgian side noted that the Russian-backed separatists continued to violate ceasefire agreements by fighting."The Russian Federation continues to violate all the agreements related to ceasefire. In the last three years, as of August 15, the Russian Federation and its armed forces have committed over 4,500 violations of ceasefire. Therefore, this is an open war," the Foreign Ministry said in a statement.The statement was signed by Georgian Foreign Minister David Zalkaliani.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson arrives to meet with Cuban President Raul Castro at a government facility in Havana, Cuba, Thursday, July 27, 2017. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)HAVANA (AP) — The Latest on developments in Cuba (all times local):11:50 a.m.U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has signaled that tough new measures against Cuba’s communist government will come from the Trump administration.Addressing an American delegation in Havana, Tillerson said the Obama administration has taken a “relatively easy line” with Havana. He said a new government is taking office and the U.S. wants a new approach that “has not been given at all.”Tillerson’s remarks Tuesday before an estimated 500 Cuban business leaders were intended to signal his policy shift from the Obama administration. It also comes on the same day as the president is holding a joint U.S.-Russia summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin.___11:20 a.m.U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson says that President Donald Trump’s tough approach to Cuba will be an example for the future, not just for his administration.Tillerson said Tuesday after meeting with Cuban business leaders in Havana that Trump would continue his predecessor’s policy of “maintaining patience” and building up support for new reforms.Tillerson said he had invited top Cuban officials to visit Washington soon to see how the country can be improved.He says that under Obama, the U.S. gave “relatively easy lines of communication” to Cuba and tried to encourage dialogue.Tillerson did not elaborate on what steps Trump’s administration could take to promote reform.___11:10 a.m.The White House is backing the Cuba plan promoted by U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson for developing economic ties with the communist government.The White House tweeted on Tuesday that “both @senateflorida & @repmarcobama have made it clear that Cuba must not get away with this and we will stand by our friends.”

T21:47:01+00:00West Africa is the third most populous region in the world but has the fourth lowest school enrolment in 2004, according to a report by the International Rescue Committee.The report, "West Africa: State of Education 2004" is based on a survey of over 15,000 schools in nine countries in the region.It found that 30 per cent of the schools (or 36.7 million students) have been seriously damaged by conflict or natural disasters, including earthquakes. This is compared to the global figure of 15 per cent.In addition, 60 per cent of West African schools (38.3 million students) were under-resourced with insufficient funding for education and health, compared to the global figure of 20 per cent.The report also found that West African schools had poor environmental conditions and sanitation, as well as poor environmental conditions in schools themselves and in the environments of the surrounding communities.The report concludes that it would be possible to close almost half (47.5 per cent) of the schools in the area, with only 4.1 per cent (8.9 million students) remaining open.This would mean, in theory, that every high school would be closed, and nearly 1.5 million young people would be able to leave the region for good. But it would also mean a huge economic decline and joblessness in a region that has experienced huge growth since the early 2000s.The total cost of the school system was estimated at $2,300 per student, but many schools in the region already have high operating costs.The report suggests that the region would have to raise the $3 billion the report says it needs to properly improve the school systems, rather than just closing them, if the region wants to achieve full economic development.

At the age of 27, the undefeated and undisputed WBA lightweight champion defended his title against the previously undefeated and undisputed WBA middleweight champion at the historic Madison Square Garden, in New York City, during the first ever broadcast of an undefeated heavyweight boxing title fight between two fighters who had never been seen competing together prior to this event.A night to remember!

Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to win a second term and continue a policy of "unwavering" support for regional states amid a steady but flimsy global economic recovery.Abenomics has achieved steady economic growth and has lifted unemployment below 4 percent. But the policy is likely to be extended until the next national election in 2021 because voter discontent still deepens as economic gains fade.Japanese voters have increasingly taken issue with Abe, who is on his third term as prime minister, due to his handling of the economic crisis stemming from the Fukushima nuclear accident.Fears that he might quit at the end of his first term have never materialized, but this year they could take a more decisive turn after a series of political setbacks and poor economic forecasts.Abe last month suffered a second blow after a string of major setbacks including a failed constitutional amendment, a government reshuffle and a lower house election called by the opposition.Abe's ruling bloc is facing a similar situation to that of the opposition during the last three decades, when powerful military and foreign governments sought to block any progress made by the prime minister during a period of relative political stability, forcing Abe to push to quickly solve problems.The ruling bloc is looking to hold on to power next year."We'll do our utmost to secure a stable Japan," said Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga on Wednesday, adding that the government was committed to Abe's second term.Analysts believe that the opposition will refrain from trying to force Abe from office.Abe's top priority in the run-up to the election will be deciding which of the six parties that are represented in the Diet -- including those from the major opposition parties -- will run for the top post.The ruling bloc has a simple majority in the upper house of parliament, but it relies on a support of at least 200 seats in the lower house to secure a majority. The conservative bloc will try to woo support from the major opposition parties by offering new and improved policies to attract the smaller parties to the bloc.Japan's economic fortunes have turned for the better but the political landscape remains shaky.

BRUTAL Bangladesh killings raise concerns about secular traditions, but few Bangladeshis have openly talked about their experiences on such a scale.More than 40 people were killed in a series of attacks in Dhaka on Friday, and hundreds more wounded, amid fears over a looming Islamic State insurgency in a country the U.S. says could be its next target.Police have arrested a leader of the suspected attack, identified as Mohammed Kamal Chowdhury. Dhaka residents say his father, also named as Chowdhury, was one of those killed.While many Bangladeshis have openly talked about losing relatives to religious violence – such as the 1982 massacre that drove hundreds of thousands from India’s eastern border – few have shared experiences in the same way.“I know many people who have lost people, but I think they keep it inside and don’t talk about it,” said Zareed Rahman, a Dhaka resident and a former politician.In a recent interview on Bangladesh’s TV, he said that his uncle was killed in 1990. “He was a priest, but he was also killed. I remember his face. You can see his face and hair,” Rahman said, recounting his uncle’s fate as the priest.“I always keep the incident inside and keep it away from my family,” he told the anchor on Friday, and then asked “when are we going to face Islamic extremism and terrorism?”The interview prompted a flood of questions on how Bangladeshis could protect themselves, and on the country’s “soft” image and how such killings could harm the country.“No one should be afraid of Bangladesh,” said the anchor. “Let’s bring out the best in each other.”The anchor also expressed optimism about Bangladesh’s chances of becoming a leader in the regional peace dialogue, something Rahman hoped would happen as soon as possible.But while the anchors’ hope appears to be tempered by the reality, many Bangladeshis – including ordinary, law-abiding citizens – are now openly talking about their experience of violence from religion and extremism, despite the country’s strong tradition of tolerance, respect for civil liberties and an independent judiciary.“

A Libyan general has seized two major terminals in the country’s oil industry, two key sources said Monday. The move is expected to increase the risk of armed conflict in the country’s energy sector, the sources said.The two terminals, located at the town of Derna, are the country’s major refineries.The military commander was reportedly a senior official of the internationally recognized government, a move that could increase risks of confrontation between the two parties.The militia leader was reportedly acting with the government’s tacit support, two of the sources said. It was not clear whether the military commander was seeking to take over the government, but he was making the move with the government’s approval, the sources said.A government spokesperson had no immediate comment on Monday’s development.Libyan forces, led by a renegade general, have been trying to unseat the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL), which operates in the country’s oil regions.

John Paul II is the former Pope who ruled the Catholic Church from 1979 until his resignation in 2005. He was born on September 4, 1933 in Poland and raised in Poland before returning to Rome for academic work.Vatican City is a Roman Catholic cathedral and the center of the Catholic Church worldwide. It is located in Vatican City, the capital city of Vatican City, and is the seat of the Holy See. It was built in 1929, by the order of the Holy See, to commemorate the visit of Pope Pius XII in 1929 to the Holy Land. It is the main building of the Catholic Church, which includes the Vatican Museum, the Roman Catholic Church, and all the dioceses throughout the world.The papacy is considered to be the ultimate authority of the Church, and to have the power to ordain and dismiss Catholic priests around the world. They use this authority to support the spiritual growth and development of the Church.All the Pope's power comes from his papal primacy or authority, which is granted by the Roman Catholic Church after the death of a Pope.It is the duty of every Catholic to act as a witness to the authority and primacy of the pope. This is especially true for Catholics in the diocese. The pope's authority is limited and not all papal actions can be legal.Pope Paul V was the third pope to have the name Pope V in a papal name, after Pope Pius I and Pope Pius XII.

A powerful earthquake that devastated the Indonesian island of Sulawesi has claimed at least 36 lives and injured at least 200, according to local officials.The deadliest and most destructive incident is yet to come when a tsunami threatens the country’s largest islands, Palu and Ternate, which were devastated by last year’s 11.1-magnitude earthquake and tsunami, said Indonesia’s disaster agency chief Sutopo Purwo Nugroho.“We have received some additional information,” he said. “The situation is still very rough … it’s still an active situation.”The earthquake destroyed tens of thousands of homes, damaged about 20,000 buildings, and displaced more than 1.4 million people.Palu and its surrounding areas, which were badly affected by last year’s tsunami, are still recovering from devastation. Palu Mayor Muhammad Iqbal said on Friday that more than 250 houses in Palu city have been destroyed.“

About 10,000 people have been evacuated from the town of Nogales by the United States Forest Service after flames from the area's last wildfire broke out in a nearby national forest, authorities said Wednesday."As of right now, the risk level for the fire is high," Nogales police Chief Joe Escalante said at a news conference.The fire is burning on both sides of the Colorado River, and was also threatening the town of Farmington, a city of some 10,000 people that lies below the river about 50 miles southeast of Salt Lake City, officials said.Two communities that are on the other side of the river have taken up emergency shelter in Phoenix.Nogales Police said there were no confirmed injuries or injuries to any firefighters or civilians.

On May 6, 2018, Ukraine opened its Eurovision Song Contest with an entry by the Ukrainian rapper "Kerfuffle" and the country's national anthem.Then, the stagehands were unable to use a sound system to play the song properly, and they had to stop the music halfway through. Kerfuffle and the crowd were left frustrated, and the Ukrainian artists were forced to cut off some songs before the competition could begin.Kerfuffle, whose full name is Sergey Khorvakov, is the owner of the Ukrainian club "Dynamika" (Kerfuffle and the Dynamika club) and is a well-known Ukrainian internet activist.On May 7, 2018, Kerfuffle started a petition on Change.org.The petition was signed by more than 10,000 people at the time of this writing.The petition claimed that:the Kyiv stage was not "ready".Kerfuffle was "trying to do his best"Ukraine's Ukrainian artists were denied their right of free expression due to political tensions and political pressure.Kerfuffle had been the only artist in Ukraine to use the stage.Kerfuffle demanded to be released from his contract and allow the Ukrainians to participate in the contest.Kerfuffle demanded a fair trial and was allowed to return.Russia, being the only party from the contest that did not send a participant, refused to participate in the contest.Then, on May 8, 2018, the European Broadcasting Union announced that it had canceled the Ukraine's entry.BBC quoted the Ukrainian broadcaster Rada as saying that:Kerfuffle's participation in the contest was conditional. We could not offer him any alternative.Kerfuffle's team had the right to submit an alternative, and it was refused.The Ukraine's government and the Eurovision organizers were trying to resolve the issue.The parties were unable to agree on what to do. The Ukraine's government refused to release the Kyiv's artist from the contract and the Eurovision organizers refused to grant the Ukraine a waiver of the "compulsory participation requirement" for Kerfuffle's participation in the contest.The Kyiv's stage was not "ready".

Hamas-affiliated media and supporters in Egypt have been using the attack on the Charlie Hebdo studio in Paris as a reason to blame Western media for the spread of terrorism across the Arab world.In Egypt, pro-Palestinian groups, including Hamas, are urging Egyptians to be against the Western media, and Egypt’s nationalistic government is calling for demonstrations against the Western media.“The West is responsible for bringing terrorism to Egypt,” said Abdallah Kamel, secretary general of the Union of Muslim Scholars, or Ummat Al-Islam.He accused Western journalists of “killing” Muslims, and said the West “should be held accountable” for the attacks. He also accused Western reporters of spreading false stories about him and other Muslim clerics.Mohamed El-Zobier, spokesman for the Islamist group Ansar Bayt al-Ma’udi, also condemned Western media coverage of the Charlie Hebdo attack, saying it did not make the people who committed the killings feel justified.“The world has been in turmoil due to the spread of the Islamic phenomenon in the Arab region,” said Abdel-Ra’ed Zitoun, spokesman for al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).According to al-Qattas, the terror network, Western reporters were “a big obstacle to our success.”But the international media did not “try to explain the situation of the countries in the Arab region” to the public, al-Qattas said. “They tried to blame the Muslim world and blame it on Western media.”The network said there were many Muslims who supported the attack in France but that “the real cause was the global spread of the Muslim phenomenon and Western media coverage that spread the narrative” that “the whole world [is] behind it.”In Libya, pro-Islamist groups are urging people to join anti-Western protests.Saba al-Fawwani, spokesman for the National Council of Resistance of Libya, or NCRL, which fought a brief NATO war there, said “the West is responsible for triggering the current crisis.”

President Donald Trump on Friday requested that the Securities and Exchange Commission revise its policies on how quarterly reports are disseminated in order to align them with the administration’s policies.In a letter to SEC Chairman Jay Clayton, Trump asked that the SEC consider modifying the process so that it is more consistent with the administration's agenda."My Administration is committed to using every legal, administrative, and technological tool available to ensure that all individuals and businesses are treated fairly.

Former Malaysian prime minister Mahathir Mohammed has denounced U.S. President George W. Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair after their meeting in New York.Mahathir said in a public statement that while he has no personal hatred towards Bush and Blair, his view on the U.S. military action against Iraq and its possible repercussions was different.The 94-year-old, who has been recovering in a hospital in the southern Malaysian state of Sabah, said the U.S. and British leaders were committing crimes in the Middle East, adding, "There is no justification to attack Iraq and there should not be any justification to go to war."

, killing 13Suicide bomber attacked a gas company in southern China on Monday, killing 13 people and wounding 10 more, officials said.At least three suicide bombers targeted the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation in Quetta, killing 13 people and wounding 10 others, the China Xinhua News Agency reported.The terrorists were wearing explosive vests and had left a car nearby before attacking, it said. The blast took place about 10am local time at the plant's main gate.Beijing earlier expressed its "great sorrow" over the incident and said China stands by Pakistan.China has long been a powerful ally of Pakistan, including supplying a large number of security forces to Pakistan. However, tensions between the countries have been on the rise lately over a long-standing dispute over Kashmir.Last week China accused Pakistan of being behind the abduction of a Chinese businessman and a scientist from Pakistan who are both now being held in Afghan jails.China said it would not interfere in the affairs of other countries but urged Pakistan to "stop threatening China over the past year".

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice says President George W. Bush has "absolutely no choice but to call on Congress" to authorize the use of force against Iraq, calling for more troops and a more aggressive, comprehensive approach to get rid of weapons of mass destruction.The White House has been divided over whether to send more troops, and whether to send them on a longer deployment. Bush has said he wants to keep troops in place until he has the political authority to get the job done.But Rice told reporters that Bush had "absolutely no choice but to call on Congress" to authorize the use of force against Iraq.Earlier, Senate Republicans said they would try and win Senate approval for a no-fly zone and increased U.S. military and intelligence assets.Rice, the nation's top diplomat, said a "bipartisan effort" was necessary for any action to end the war.But Sen. Joseph Lieberman, who introduced legislation in February that called for a no-fly zone, said it was impossible now for the nation to go back and change the course of the war in Iraq, though he said Congress could help move the nation on the right path."

Protesters(Last Updated On: August 22, 2019)New Delhi, Aug 22: Indian Parliament was once again disrupted by the protesters as many of them have gathered in their thousands to protest against the amendments tabled in the Lok Sabha which has been tabled in the Rajya Sabha too.The ongoing protests in India against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act have been going on for over three months now.

Photo Credit: Wikimedia, CC-BY 4.0New York (PIX11) — American lawmakers Tuesday called for stiffer sanctions against Russia, following a slew of recent events that have shaken the U.S.-Russia relationship, especially over Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.Advertisement“To be sure, the United States has been the world leader in defense of its democratic ideals,” U.S. Rep. Eliot Engel told Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, during a closed meeting Monday on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly, as reported by Fox News.Engel, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, has been leading calls in the U.S. House of Representatives for tougher sanctions against Russia, and said that the U.S. and Russia should step up the rhetoric during their upcoming meetings in New York.“It is time for the United States and Russia to step up their rhetoric and threats in regard to international security,” he said, according to the AP.President Donald Trump has yet to comment on the matter, though he has previously been outspoken about the need for a tougher response to Russia.The meeting between Putin and Engel came amid a slew of other high-level meetings between U.S. and Russian officials. In a separate meeting, Trump announced his intention to hold a meeting with Putin and other leaders during the annual gathering of the General Assembly in New York.Trump made the announcement after meeting other world leaders Monday in New York, where he reaffirmed his commitment to U.S.-led international organizations, including NATO, and urged them to work on countering North Korea.The North Korea summit has been put on hold, and the summit scheduled for November 9 in Singapore between Trump and Kim Jong Un will now take place next month, Trump said.“We’ll see if we can get that done,” he said, according to AP. “It’s a big one. It’s a big deal. It’s a big challenge.”

(AFRICAN EXAMINER) – A Nigerian family has spoken out after saying they believe a secret recording of their missing daughter is a last surviving image of Dapchi girls.In an audio of the last family’s conversation with another family member, the family claimed they believed Dapchi girls’ secret recording is evidence of the Dapchi tragedy.Dapchi girls were abducted by suspected Boko Haram Islamists on January 16. They were reportedly released several days later in February.The family member who was contacted by the family said the family believed the girl has been sent to another country.“I was not able to get through to her on WhatsApp, but my brother told me that she said someone was trying to tell her the person that is keeping her is telling her to not do a certain thing,” he said.He said: “She was telling me the person telling her this is going to get her killed, and that she should call the police.”He said the girl was asked to call the girl that her husband is in the army, and who is the woman that is keeping her.“She was also told not to report to anybody,” he said.The family member told the story to the AP that same day.“In the voice recording, what was the girl’s husband saying and why was he so angry? Did she give out any names? We need to know. She also told me the phone number that she is receiving calls from and the voice coming from was not her husband’s voice. They are not speaking with her voice.”The family member also revealed that the family member who confirmed the recording was not able to get through to the girl as WhatsApp had not been working and the phone number had been disconnected.“She told me she is sure that Dapchi girls are alive and talking. We need to find them and make sure they are safe. I know it will take a long time to get hold of the video because DAPCHI GIRLS ARE ALIVE AND TALKING!”The family member said he would report the matter to the appropriate authorities.Earlier this year, five Dapchi girls, including the missing Dapchi girl, were found dead in a forest.

LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s new leader, has vowed to make a political fight of the Brexit negotiations with the European Union, but the Labor Party has rejected his demands for a “special” Brexit deal to try to secure votes on the final agreement.Johnson, who was elected leader of the Conservative Party on Friday, has signaled his ambitions to negotiate a Brexit deal with the EU, but warned that he would not put up with a “joke” of a deal that would leave Britain tied to the EU indefinitely.Johnson says the UK could hold a referendum next year about whether to accept the terms of Brexit. He says he would be willing to put an unpopular proposal on the table to keep the country in the bloc’s common fisheries policy and other agreements, but he would also not accept a bad deal.Labour’s main leadership is now facing a crucial decision. The party’s official position is still that Britain should leave the EU on the terms set out in the Benn Act passed by parliament earlier this year. However, many senior members have indicated that they would give it more than one chance to see if it would be able to be changed. Johnson has promised to force a referendum, which would require the support of Labour’s parliamentary majority, if he cannot negotiate a good deal.Labour’s Brexit spokesperson Keir Starmer has said his party would only agree to a deal that it felt satisfied with.“When it is ready we will put it to the vote,” Starmer said. “We are very clear that there is no deal that we would put to the vote for the first two and a half weeks of December and that’s a fact.”“We are going to have to go through the processes to try to make sure that a deal can get through parliament, but I’m absolutely certain that there will be a deal for Labour that will be good for the British people,” he said.Johnson’s Brexit chief Dominic Cummings had a similar view. “I think Keir Starmer and Corbyn are very close to actually making a bad deal,” Cummings said.

Than Previously ThoughtThe effects of climate change can already be seen, but as the world moves to curb emissions, that list will grow. Here are five of the biggest changes in the process."This one is going to be a real challenge because it's been a little bit underestimated. But the impacts of climate change are going to get stronger and bigger and happen more quickly and sooner than previously thought."—Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University, via USA TodayThe United States is already feeling its effects of climate change. For example, hurricanes are more powerful and wetter because global warming is leading to wetter and more volatile seas."The longer the warm-air circulation over the ocean goes on, the more water is going to be evaporated into the air and the more water is going to be absorbed by the atmosphere," said Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University, via USA Today. The increased moisture makes hurricanes more intense and devastating.But there's no turning back the clock to fix climate change. The U.S. is expected to spend as much on green energy in the next two decades as the entire budget of France in the 20th century."It's kind of a no-brainer in my mind, really. We know we're going to have impacts of climate change. We know we're going to have heat waves and we know we're going to have sea level rise. So it is kind of this no-brainer, this is what we're going to do," said Steve Williams, climate analyst at the US National Weather Service. "In terms of the overall impact, I don't think anyone is particularly worried by that."The effects of climate change will be felt even more in the next 100 years, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)."This is a really tough task because this is going to be a very long term impact that's going to come, but that's part of what makes climate change such a big problem. And we don't really have that amount of time to fix it because these problems are going to last and people are going to be impacted," said Williams. "So that's the tough part.

Islamabad [Pakistan], Nov 6 (ANI): Pakistani Taliban, which has been on the verge of capturing the key northwestern district of South Waziristan, has withdrawn from the district, South Waziristan District Police said on Wednesday.Pakistan's Foreign Office in a press statement said that the Pakistani government is committed to the Afghan people and has supported the Afghan government in their peace process.Also Read | India’s COVID-19 Tally Hits 26-Million, Single-Day High, 1,000 Deaths Reported.Earlier in the day, South Waziristan District Police had confirmed that the Pakistani Taliban had withdrawn from the district.According to the provincial police, Pakistani Taliban have withdrawn from the South Waziristan District.Also Read | Pakistan PM Imran Khan to Discuss Situation in Afghanistan With US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan.The announcement came after an earlier Taliban announcement that they were leaving the Pakistani district of Waziristan.The Taliban, which has been on the verge of capturing the key northwestern district of South Waziristan, had announced earlier that they were leaving the district, South Waziristan District Police.At least seven Afghan soldiers had been killed in South Waziristan area earlier, said South Waziristan Police.Pakistani Taliban (Taliban) is a terrorist organisation banned in Pakistan and a designated global terrorist by the United Nations.The Pakistani government and the military have conducted an offensive against the Taliban.

byThe Exaggerator took another step forward.The 5-year-old gelding claimed his second Preakness Stakes title, and fifth in the series.The victory gives him 15 wins in a career that began in 2014.The win gives the horse a 9-5 advantage in the series and a 13-10 advantage in the overall stakes.This is the first time that the horse, ridden by David Miller, has won the Preakness Stakes. Miller became the first rider to win the Preakness Stakes with a riding partner and riding a horse.The victory, which also won the Kentucky Derby, is his third Derby in a row.

By KELLY LUNAKTroy High School’s dance program is a safe place for its dance students in a tough neighborhood in Boston’s Back Bay neighborhood where an estimated one in four youths are victims of violence or other kinds of serious crime.In recent years, Troy High School’s dance program has been transformed by two young choreographers, Jennifer Brown and Erin Noyes, whose passion and experience in dance programming has created a safe place for students to learn and to learn to perform the most challenging styles of modern and classical dance, including dance that uses only body language, movement, and dance elements such as musical and visual expression.“

A new Gallup poll shows a sharp decline in Americans' confidence in their country, from a strong 90 percent saying the United States had an attractive future to a more modest 81 percent now.The "trust in U.S. leadership" index is the lowest since December 2001.One key finding: that the level of optimism about a U.S. outcome—from a negative 27 percent to a positive 19 percent—dissipates among young Americans. The "generation gap" between those under 30 and those over 65 has gotten wider during that period, according to Gallup.An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll also finds a sharp drop in young Americans' confidence in the U.S.Overall confidence level dropped from 94 percent to 72 percent.

of South Sudan ConflictThe withdrawal of Chad from the Central African Republic is a risk that South Sudan’s warring parties may use to regain control of oil-rich areas in their conflict zone, the United Nations said on Friday.Nations and countries that support South Sudan’s peace effort called for restraint after Chadian forces were withdrawn this week.Chad’s government said it decided to withdraw in response to the South Sudanese government’s move to grant an amnesty for rebels who had captured the northern town of Yomtew and some areas of the capital, Juba.A Sudanese army offensive on Tuesday night had killed at least 11 people in the South Sudanese capital of Juba, according to sources.“There are concerns in the international community over Chadian involvement in South Sudan’s conflict,” said United Nations deputy spokesman Farhan Haq, without elaborating.Chad, which has been a staunch backer of South Sudan’s secession from Sudan in 2011, has about 5,000 troops in the CAR.The Chadian defence ministry says it has “provided military logistical and combat support” to the South Sudanese army and its allied militias.Since South Sudan’s independence in 2011, warring groups in the country have been fighting to claim land they see as theirs for the benefit of ethnic groups.A peace deal signed in September, 2011, and repeated in April last year, aimed to settle the conflict which killed more than one million people.South Sudan’s government says the rebels still have the support of “armed” non-government armed groups.The rebels say the ceasefire has not yet been respected, and accuse the Chadian government of refusing to give them weapons.“

General Electric has announced that CEO Jeff Immelt is resigning and that his successor will be Denny Lynch.This is certainly not the kind of message GE needs going into the holiday season. With so much uncertainty regarding the fiscal year 2017 results and with the market being so sensitive about the potential for a rate hike next month, the move by Lynch will likely be welcomed by many.This was a long time coming as Immelt had been under tremendous scrutiny from the shareholders regarding GE’s financial condition and its ability to return value to its shareholders. In his letter of resignation, he did say that he would leave the Board in good standing at the end of the day, which was certainly a sign that he was stepping down.This move comes on the heels of a major restructuring that will lead to the sale of GE’s entire industrial business. This restructuring was the company’s first step towards its goal of selling all of its industrial units.

Post After AttacksIslam Times - Qatar pulled all its troops from its Djibouti-Eritrea border post after attacks on the soldiers.The troops were withdrawn from the Djibouti-Eritrea border post in Al Fula region after a wave of attacks. On Tuesday, three soldiers were killed and five others were injured in an attack by suspected militants. The Qatar-Eritrea border post is located in Al Fula village.Al Fula is also the headquarters of the Qatari border guards and it is the only frontier crossing between the two countries. Qatar is also the only country that allows Qatari troops to transit through its borders.Qatar’s foreign affairs minister, Mohammed Mohammed Al-Thani, is on a two-day visit to Djibouti. Mohammed said in an interview with Djiboutian radio that Qatar and Djibouti are working to improve security and stability in their common region.

On 10 October, the exit poll was announced for Lithuania's Parliamentary election. The exit poll shows that the ruling Democratic Rally (D&R) party will lose to the Lithuanian Democratic Party for the first time in over half a century.The Lithuanian Democratic Party will not win its fourth consecutive term in power after it lost the October 9 poll to the Lithuanian Democratic Union (LDA) with 45.54% of the vote. The party will however still take the majority in the 80-member parliament as D&R did not enter into an electoral coalition with other parties, and will be able to work with the Social Democratic Centre (SSD).The D&R party currently holds 48 seats, a three-point increase for the last poll.

Beijing is looking to put an end to a long list of state-owned firms across China implicated in corruption scandals.The State Council on Friday issued new regulations to inspect the assets of major state enterprises in a move aimed at rooting out corruption.The State Council said it would strengthen its coordination with the country's Central Military Government to prevent the theft of state assets by the armed forces and law enforcement agencies.The regulations also require state-owned enterprises to establish a special department and promote new technologies to reduce losses of state-owned enterprises through mergers and acquisitions.Some recent incidents, such as the one involving the Guosheng Group, have caused controversy about the extent to which the national security apparatus can spy on Chinese citizens and businesses for use in anti-corruption efforts.Authorities said Guosheng is one of the Guosheng Group companies, along with the Dalian Xingdao Group and Jiangsu Tianyong Group, that had provided equipment to the North Korean nuclear program in 2014-2015.

The leader of a Toronto mosque has resigned over the weekend after saying an imam's comment about genital mutilation was an example of "real Islam."Imam Mohamed F. M. Farha — who ran the Toronto Islamic Community Centre — has resigned after saying that he could see "genital mutilation done in the community" due to "real Islam" and "real men" he has seen "hurt" after attending a Muslim funeral.Farha said that he had been talking with a woman "who is the granddaughter of a female family member of a young Muslim man who was killed in the 9/11 attacks" who described how her family member was attacked. Farha added that while the woman was "dealing with the tragedy" in that attack, she had to witness the attack in order to understand what it is to be Muslim in the modern world."[The woman] had said that there was no way for her to have felt safe when she was young, because the Muslim community where she was from does not have female leaders who are trained to talk about those types of issues," Farha said. "I have been talking to her since I was asked to resign by the community on Saturday."Fara told the Canadian Press that he plans to attend a training session on the issue of genital mutilation "as soon as possible."Fara said the decision came about after the Muslim community in the community reached out to him to express their support for him.

: ReportChina will start building a U.S. assembly plant in 2019, reports CNBC. The news comes amid the ongoing trade war between the two nations.CNBC reports that China will start building a U.S. assembly plant in 2019, a move that could help bring the two nations closer to an end to the tariff battle that has strained commerce relations for over a year.This would help the economy as both nations work to end the trade war with a less bitter feeling.Currently, neither China nor the U.S. have a car factory in operation to produce vehicles for American consumers.China already manufactures cars in the world's two largest economies, so having the U.S. take a look into doing the same would make economic sense as both countries look to bolster their economies.But how long it would take for the U.S. market to be flooded with vehicles from China remains to be seen, and the CNBC report cites no timetable.There were some hopes that the U.S. would agree to purchase Chinese-made electric cars from the company BYD when the two nations signed a memorandum of understanding in 2018.Still, no official word or official announcement has been made since 2018. A BYD electric car was recently unveiled in the Chinese market.One of the biggest reasons for the Trump administration wanting to cut a deal with China on trade is that the president claims that the U.S. has "little to gain" from a trade deal with the Chinese and that the trade war is bad for the U.S. business community.U.S. President Donald Trump is currently in a trade war with China, which is also in the process of putting a tariff on another U.S. product: steel.Read the original article on CNBC.
