Three Southern California Catholic dioceses say they have been targeted by a lawsuit alleging that they covered up the widespread sexual abuse of minors by priests in their churches, an allegation the dioceses deny.In a statement Tuesday, the dioceses of San Bernardino, Santa Barbara and Orange said they have done what they can to help victims of abuse by clergy, and that they continue to cooperate with law enforcement, as well as the investigation of clergy accused of abusing children.But the lawsuit filed Tuesday by two victims' rights attorneys contends that a series of bishops in Southern California covered up widespread abuse by priests and then concealed their cover-up by hiding documents, making it impossible for victims to report abuses or to seek justice. The lawsuit filed in Orange County alleges that more than 300 children in the Los Angeles Archdiocese may have been abused at the hands of Catholic priests over an 80-year span beginning in 1949.The lawsuit alleges that the dioceses, particularly in Southern California, covered up abusive priests by failing to keep accurate records of allegations of abuse and hiding documents about how the dioceses handled allegations. The plaintiffs allege that the dioceses allowed abusive priests to continue working within parishes and that they were also unwilling to deal with the victims and report cases of abuse.The allegations include that some dioceses allowed the abusive priests to continue working while they continued to be members of the community and kept church documents about allegations of abuse and attempts to cover up accusations from church officials.The lawsuits contend that the dioceses failed to investigate or protect the children who had been abused or did nothing about the records of abuse by abusing priests that they had already kept."These children have suffered the most grievous of injuries," according to the lawsuit, filed by two law firms, the National Child & Family Coalition in Sacramento and the Law Center for Children & Families in Los Angeles.The case seeks to force the Diocese of Orange to make public all records relating to claims of abuse against priests and to pay damages to all victims.The Orange Diocese denied the allegations in a statement Tuesday."While the Orange Diocese cannot, and will not, comment on the specific details of each case regarding which our priests are alleged to have abused children, we welcome the opportunity to examine the accusations," said Bishop John F. Vincenzo of Orange.Bishop Victor J.

Over FilmIn a lawsuit filed this week, horror film director Wes Craven and comedian Pauly Shore claim the other used their property unconstitutionally, and the lawsuit seeks unspecified damages.According to court documents obtained by the Hollywood Reporter, the lawsuit was filed against Pauly Shore, the owner and creator of Pauly Shore & the Shore Family Daze, an internet service of jokes posted on the web by Shore.Shore claims in the lawsuit that Craven is seeking the same amount of money he lost in a lawsuit against him when Shore published the original sketches and songs and videos without permission.This is not the first lawsuit between Craven and Pauly Shore, who was Craven's friend.Shore was awarded an injunction in 2014 after Craven sued him for not giving Craven credit.The case is currently on hold because of the coronavirus, but that isn’t to say it can’t be renewed.Wes Craven on the other hand has been hit with a lawsuit by a friend and actor, Pauly Shore, who was Craven's buddy for years and has now filed against the filmmaker.In a recent interview with Sirius XM, Craven revealed he and Shore were arguing about what to do about Pauly Shore."

sBurundian political parties are required to register voters as citizens of the country, but if the government were to allow a “free press,” it could allow foreign journalists."The government is saying that they are preparing for elections, but at the moment the media cannot enter the country,” said Burundi Commissioner for Freedom of Press, Robert Mugisha.Mugisha was addressing the press on Tuesday, after a session of the ruling National Patriotic Front party’s Standing Council, which was held at a school in the north Burundian town of Kayanza.“The government will not allow foreign journalists to enter the country because it means that they would not be able to report as citizens as they say,” he added.On February 5, Burundi Foreign Affairs minister, Oly Ilunga, declared on Twitter that the country’s authorities would “allow international journalists, but the restrictions include the limitation of access to the capital city [Kigali]” and its environs.Burundi is due to hold elections in 2020, with the President of the African Union’s (AU) member states to head a 15-member electoral commission.There are already three parties already in place, and four others have expressed an intention to run. However, another five will be allowed to field candidates.

in 'Sci-fi-Reality'In a future where humans have become the primary explorers on a planet millions of miles away, scientists and space enthusiasts are working to create a realistic world with enough data to help shape the future of humanity.The world's space community is also trying to come up with a realistic and realistic scenario that would allow humans to leave Earth.For years, the science community has been working to develop instruments and methods for future missions to Mars and, someday, even beyond.For example, the Mars Exploration Rover (MER) mission aims to gather a "snapshot" of the Martian atmosphere every day for two and a half years before launching, in a plan called "the Martian Inoxidator." That mission is expected to begin in the summer of 2014.A second mission, known as "Mars Hand Lens Interferometer," or MHLI, will collect data from the Mars surface once the MER mission concludes in August 2018."That was the first step to establishing the ability to actually have a sample sent from Mars," said Thomas Zurbuchen, a senior science adviser at NASA. [In Pictures: Images of Mars' Red Planet]"We think that we could do it tomorrow, but we need to get samples, and we need to bring them back," he said.The MER mission will carry eight sample tubes that would be mounted on the rover. Once the samples are collected by MER, they will travel to Mars' surface, where they would be deposited on Earth's surface.In addition, the Curiosity rover mission will examine Mars' atmosphere and analyze the chemical compositions of rocks. That work is expected to be completed by late 2016.Both the Curiosity and MHLI missions are being managed by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, with funding from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). The European Space Agency, or ESA, manages the ExoMars rover mission on behalf of the European Union.The MHLI mission will be led by a team of scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). Other teams of scientists are working on a variety of other missions to Mars, including the Mars Odyssey orbiter, which is orbiting the Red Planet. NASA and ESA are developing the next generation of robotic spacecraft that will explore the planets in the asteroid belt, known as the Oort Cloud."

16:45 by Yoshinori OnagaYoshinori Onaga (left), Prime Minister of Japan, and Nobuo Kishi (center) chief of the Cabinet Office, hold a news conference at his residence in Tokyo, Friday, after meeting with Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi of Japan. (Credit: Kyodo News via AP)A new Japanese foreign minister will be chosen next week to take on the post on a long-term plan to boost cooperation with the U.S. and other countries.Japan's outgoing foreign minister, who also heads the Cabinet Office, told reporters Friday that he will seek to strengthen ties with the United States and other countries in Asia.Minister Toshimitsu Motegi said his government will start a search for a new foreign minister in the second half of next week. Foreign Minister Motegi was selected to carry on the reform project begun by his predecessor, Fumio Kishida, who in July served as the country's first foreign minister since the abolition of the war cabinet.Before he was made prime minister, Kishida sought to boost ties with the U.S. and other countries in Asia and in Europe. Japan's ties with those countries have improved dramatically, but it needs to go further.

The latest news from NASA:The space shuttle Atlantis will remain at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida until April, according to the agency. NASA has confirmed that Atlantis remains in the middle of its normal maintenance cycle.The space shuttle will undergo a total of 16 months of work, according to NASA.During the time the work will be focused on the Atlantis wing and vehicle components, the wing’s air tanks, and some of Atlantis’ cargo.The work is being planned to be completed in time for the Atlantis’s scheduled departure.This latest delay of the shuttle, due to the wet conditions in the area, will only increase the cost of flight delays. The space shuttle Atlantis has already experienced two other flight delays this year due to wet weather conditions. The agency plans to add fuel reserves into the shuttle, which will allow the shuttle to stay on course through potential weather risks, according to space analyst James Epps.Atlantis will remain at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida until April, according to the agency.NASA’s next flight will be the Orion spacecraft which will carry astronauts to explore the moon and other celestial bodies.

KABUL, Afghanistan—Afghanistan is trying to eliminate private security companies, officials and officials said Tuesday.Officials said that in a meeting held in Kabul on Tuesday the government issued a decree abolishing a company that had been providing security and protection to high-ranking government officials.Afghanistan has a law that bans any private security company from providing security to the government.The meeting came after an increase in attacks and a deadly siege by suspected Taliban militants against the Interior Ministry.Afghan President Hamid Karzai and other high-ranking officials also attended the meeting. They gave instructions to improve security in various parts of Kabul.Kabul has been hit hard by an increase in violence in recent weeks, in which a car bomb near the Ministry of Interior has killed at least five people.The Taliban in January took over the Afghan presidential palace, which was previously held by Karzai's rival.According to reports, the Taliban released a video on Monday that showed them taking a group of children and their parents hostage, saying they would demand a release of prisoners they had held in recent attacks.The release of the hostages would be part of the process of Afghan leaders making peace, according to a group called the Peace Council.

by Michelle MartinOn Sunday evening the UK saw its worst-ever death toll linked to coronavirus, with 548 deaths reported in just one day — an astonishing figure.This was not expected, and this too is not unexpected: this is a pandemic, a global health emergency. But to many people it is also a personal tragedy and a national emergency. It feels like a national tragedy, the likes of which we never even expected.There is no greater illustration than the reaction from people and the government.It has been a huge and overwhelming effort to combat this global threat. While the numbers are staggering and many people, businesses and organisations have fallen on hard times, some people have responded to the crisis with incredible kindness and generosity.From small donations of food and money to the most heartfelt pleas for volunteers, to donations to food banks, to help with medical costs and for personal protective equipment, the reaction has been immense and deeply moving.It also highlights how people are feeling and reacting to all this in different ways. It is almost as if some people are doing it as a social duty to give back, whilst some are just doing it because they want to feel part of the response in some way.The government has also offered a huge response, a huge and overwhelming amount of money to help fight the disease. The vast majority of people have done so incredibly well, donating to food banks and offering financial help, without expecting in return any sort of reward.However, many are still feeling the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, and are looking for something to do, and this is where social media comes in.It is an enormous help for many, and has been a huge help for many people, and also for others too. For some, social media gives them a way to voice their opinions and find their way to people who need them. It lets them reach people on a topic of interest for them.

in ReportBEIRUT, July 16, 2014 (ENS) – A United Nations report has detailed the situation in Syria – including the use of cluster munitions and barrel bombs – in an unprecedented number of attacks.While Syria appears to have a “relatively low” number of cluster bombs in its arsenal, the report indicates that in the first six months of this year alone, more than 500,000 cluster munitions were used during fighting across Syria’s nine provinces, accounting for more than half of all cluster-weapon use in Syria this year.During this period, an average of four to eight victims were killed per hour, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said in the report, released today.The report noted that for the first time ever, the use of cluster munitions was a cause for concern in Syria because it would put the population in an already dangerous situation and risk further displacement.“Although some progress has been made in Syria regarding the use of cluster munitions, the report demonstrates that this trend may continue in light of the continued use of cluster munitions in Syrian military operations in the first half of this year,” said Valerie Amos, the UN Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs, in her introduction to the report.The report – one of more than 10 UN reports issued today concerning Syria’s civil war – includes an extensive survey of what happened in Syria in 2013.The report found a steady uptick in the use of barrel bombs, which are non-explosive explosive launchers packed with a large quantity of chemical materials, including chlorine.“The use of chemical weapons in Syria should be condemned by everyone, including the international community,” Amos said.Barbarium bombs were used throughout Syria this year, and were most often used in the first half of 2014.

ISLAMABAD — The United States has warned that increased violence is "certain" and said any peace deal with the Taliban must focus on Afghanistan's economy and prevent it from becoming a " breeding ground" for militants.The U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, and his Pakistani counterpart, Asad Umar, met for more than 10 hours Saturday in Islamabad.Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid said Sunday that the U.S. ambassador and his Pakistani counterpart "discussed the ongoing dialogue process," but said there was no immediate progress."They assured us that they would take this matter into account in future but we are not seeing any serious effort to resume the talks," he said.The U.S. and NATO formally began peace talks with the Taliban in Doha, Qatar, in March last year, with the aim of opening up talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban about the end of the 22-year-old war. The talks have never been seriously progressed.The Afghan government rejected calls by U.S. President Donald Trump for increased U.S. involvement in the talks, arguing that the U.S. military was already committed and that it was not needed. Trump also threatened to remove support if he was not satisfied.Trump also demanded that the Islamic insurgent group halt attacks on U.S. and other foreign troops in Afghanistan.The Taliban has claimed responsibility for several large-scale attacks in Kabul in recent weeks.A spokesman for Taliban leader Haider al-Abd, who attended the meeting in Islamabad on Sunday, denied any progress."We discussed the current situation of the country. No further steps will be taken," Zabihullah told The Associated Press. "The Afghan side is ready for further talks with the U.S. side."Abd said the Taliban would be open to talking with the Afghan government but that the government must also be ready for such talks."For them to agree on a cease-fire in the past, they have to show an action to that," he said. "After that, we will discuss with them about the path for the future."While it is still not clear how the new U.S. strategy and the future of the Afghan peace talks will affect the new policy that President Trump has announced on Afghanistan, the Afghan government did not deny that U.S.

Despite reform, Native American women still face high rates of crime. A 2010 study from the University of California-Santa Barbara and the National Center for Educational Statistics found that in some Native American communities, the risk of violent crime was 10 times greater than in communities where only 20 percent of residents are Native American.While the criminal justice reform movement has made a dent in reducing violent crime rates overall, Native American women’s safety remains a serious concern. To remedy that, law enforcement agencies and tribal leaders need to address the unique challenges Native American women face and ensure that crime victims receive the protection they deserve.According to the U.S. Department of Justice, Native American women were the victims of crimes at four times the rate of white women. In California, Native American women are 3.5 times as likely to be arrested for crimes as white women, and are 1.7 times as likely to be victims of violence.A 2007 study from the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics found that while violent crime rates decreased in communities where Native American women were the primary victim group, their rates of robbery continued to be higher than in communities where more than half of residents were Native American.

For 'Attacking' IndiaWashington [US], July 10 (ANI): The United States, on Thursday, called for an end to the boycott of Indian opposition leader Sonia Gandhi for her role in the violence that shook her home.India had requested the United States to end the suspension of assistance to Sri Lanka's Government after a special United Nations (UN) committee recommended that it be suspended. The US had refused to lift the suspension of aid until the Sri Lankan government takes certain actions. The country had also sought the restoration of certain development assistance suspended by the US government for Sri Lanka.The US is suspending assistance to Sri Lanka because it will not commit to action to achieve the outcome of a special committee of the UN human rights body, which recommended that the United States suspend assistance to the government of Sri Lanka in response to violent protests between pro-and-anti forces in that country.Also Read | US to Resume Financial Assistance to S Sri Lanka: Report.The suspension of assistance to Sri Lanka was approved by the US Senate. The suspension will continue until the government of Sri Lanka takes certain steps to prevent further violence, including holding political dialogue and releasing those who are still under house arrest, in accordance with the Special Committee's report.The UN Special Rapporteur for human rights in Sri Lanka, Navi Pillay, had called upon the Security Council to suspend the suspension of financial assistance to Sri Lanka and take other actions to maintain a conducive climate in that country, especially in view of the ongoing violence, the Human Rights Council, after the country had lost the Special Rapporteur's mandate. The special rapporteur also urged the member States of the Human Rights Council to take steps to ensure that the country has an effective framework for addressing the human rights concerns arising out of the violence, in particular including by encouraging the government and security forces to restore the rule of law, take prompt steps to ensure the safety of all communities, including the protection of journalists and ensure an independent, impartial, thorough and independent investigation into all allegations of the use of excessive force and other violations of human rights, ensure appropriate and prompt redress of the rights concerns, prevent further violence and provide assistance to the affected communities to help restore the social, economic, cultural and educational development of Sri Lanka.In April, the US State Department had issued the first travel warning on Sri Lanka, saying that it would be reevaluating travel to the country.

WASHINGTON — President Obama was sworn in as the 39th president of the United States Wednesday evening at the U.S. Capitol.Obama was sworn in at 7:27 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time (10:27 P.M. Central) via the Internet.Obama, the son of a former Illinois state senator, won a historic upset victory against Mitt Romney in the presidential election, claiming a majority of the popular vote.The president delivered a brief speech that was streamed live on the Internet.“We are a nation divided, a nation that is bitterly divided on matters of race, a nation that seems to be sliding toward a second civil war,” Obama said.“We are a nation that believes that every single person in America, regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, economic background, religion — every single one of us — should be treated as if they had nothing else to lose but their lives, their dignity, and everything they have to win,” he said.Obama took over as president in January 2009 after he had won the election by less than two points of President George W. Bush.Obama’s four years have seen a steady recovery in the U.S. economy and the decline of terrorism.A report released today by the Federal Reserve says the U.S. has regained its manufacturing-driven growth following a recession that started in December 2007 and was only officially declared over in June 2009.The report notes that the nation had added 2.7 million private sector jobs since 2007 and a further 1.6 million in 2012.The economy is now experiencing a second period of recovery.“All indications are that this recovery continues to be strong and that it will become a virtuous circle,” President Obama said.President Obama also signed eight executive orders during his first 100 days in office. Among them:“We will continue to invest in science, in infrastructure. We will make sure that every child in America gets a decent education, and that every single child can succeed in this country.”“We’ll make sure that every American has access to affordable health insurance, and that every American can afford the prescription drugs they need, and that every American has access to quality, affordable college education.”“

BANGKOK — Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha survived a no-confidence motion.This afternoon the lower house of parliament approved the no-confidence motion presented by the Democrat Party led by Pramon Chartmasri, an independent member of parliament in the lower house who is also an associate justice of Thailand's Constitutional Court.The motion was presented to make sure Prayut's government was able to hold onto power ahead of a referendum due in the second half of next year.The no-confidence motion was rejected in two earlier votes held in the lower house.Pramon Chartmasri said that the vote had not been easy."It is true that there are people who want to support the government and support it. The same people want to oppose it," Pramon said."There are some people who did not believe that this government could last. And there are other people who support this government and want to support it," he said."This motion to save the government was more difficult than the previous two motions to save the government."The vote was supported by 13 out of the 16 parties, including the ruling pro-army Future Forward Party and the opposition pro-democracy party the United Front.

in NigeriaThe UN has said that a robust Ebola recovery strategy is needed in Nigeria to help protect citizens from new waves of the virus.A recovery plan in Nigeria is needed now more than ever as a second wave of Ebola is taking hold, according to a new report published by UN officials.The report titled, "Seconding the World to the Fight against Ebola", notes that Nigeria has had an "excellent response" to the first wave of Ebola, as it was able to contain the virus within its borders, but that the country has seen a rapid resurgence of new cases in some regions, particularly in West Africa.In the West African region, the outbreak has taken a particularly deadly toll because it's also the region that has had the most access to vaccines.The UN officials say that in the absence of robust national recovery strategies, and effective vaccine delivery system, the threat of a new wave of the Ebola virus in Nigeria remains considerable.The report says that it would not be sufficient to contain Ebola."Without the right recovery strategy and vaccine distribution systems, it is difficult to imagine a path to containment of the virus for the near future," it says.The new outbreak is especially concerning because of the fact that it has affected communities that had little exposure in the first round, and that the vaccines have not been as robustly rolled out in the region as they have in more established and developed countries.Some African countries, including Nigeria, have a lower immunization rate than other parts of the world.The report says that a vaccination strategy with a strong focus on protecting and protecting communities and communities, and a strategy to prevent the spread of the disease, is necessary if the world is to "turn a corner and reduce the threat of the virus."

The Argentine pope Francis has been outspoken about the plight of migrants during his visit to Bulgaria on Monday, April 26.The visit is an "opportunity to reflect on some problems that may exist, and to create solutions, for which we need to be much more open to the possibility of an effective and effective immigration policy that involves solidarity and solidarity in favor of all the population of Europe," he said.Pope Francis also made clear that he is not going to endorse or support the policy of non-importation of refugees and migrants.He said that he is not seeking to endorse any particular migration policy. He reiterated his statement regarding migrants and asylum seekers in an interview that was aired on Monday's program of Bulgaria's Channel 1."I am not trying to be on the same page as the Greek, Italian or Bulgarian policy, or any of the other policies that are in favour of those arriving, and those fleeing," he said.He continued, "I am calling to be open-minded. I am calling for our European citizenship to allow us to receive the migrants, asylum seekers, without the risk of the expulsion of people, of which we have some in our country. These migrants are living in extreme conditions. They are being held in detention in Greece. Some people say that it is a human right to take them. There is not a human right to force people to come to Europe."The Pope emphasized the need for solidarity between migrants and asylum seekers because he noted that countries have a responsibility to protect and care for those who enter their country.According to the Vatican, the Pope emphasized the importance of the right to a dignified stay of asylum-seekers in the European Union.As he did in his interviews with the Greek bishops, the Pope told the Bulgarian people that he considers the protection of refugees and migrants to be of "impeccable ethical value," and that "it is imperative that the European Union be a force for global peace and social justice."According to the Bulgarian government, Pope Francis visited Bulgaria, where he met with the country's president, Rumen Radev, and a number of other officials, including Prime Minister Boyko Borissov, a government official, and bishops.Earlier on Monday, during a visit to the Greek Orthodox church in Nicomedia, the Pope visited the church of St.

The elections in CAR are drawing to a close. The United Nations has warned that over 100 000 voting papers and electronic devices have been destroyed and are yet to be retrieved.This is what is making it difficult for the Commission of Presidential Elections to declare a winner as it could be challenged by the losing candidate.On Tuesday, the Electoral Board of the CAR held a press briefing to address the issue, where several top members of the political parties addressed them. Some of them insisted that their party won and would win the elections.The electoral board, however, explained that the process in the country requires a complex computer software in order for the results to be transmitted from the central data banks to the electoral commission. The central banks hold over 10 000, 000 of these data sheets."It is expected that there will be an overwhelming response, hence the delay. The commission would work towards restoring confidence to the general public by addressing their grievances as soon as possible,” the EC said.The CARs presidential election has been suspended since mid-August due to alleged electoral fraud. The EC said that the electoral commission is going to use satellite equipment that can capture information from the national electoral databases and transmit it to the commission’s headquarters in Lofa in Treloar, Togo.The EC had planned to conduct a re-run, if any, within a week, however, the CARs electoral commission decided to delay the elections in order for the EC to work on a new system to capture information from the databases.However, Togo’s President Faure Gnassingbe announced his decision to withdraw his candidacy for the upcoming elections, stating that he will remain on leave as head of state to ensure stability in the country.Mali, which is also embroiled in a political and religious crisis, said that it will hold elections after March 12th, 2019, as scheduled, without any delay.

Mariya Tymoshenko is not in the Ukrainian government, nor is she at the current meeting between the leaders of Ukraine, the United States, and Russia in Minsk. That doesn’t make her any less important to Ukraine, however.The fact that Tymoshenko is not there has a lot to do with how this week's talks are playing out. If the leaders of Ukraine and the United States don't get along, what good are the talks they have?The talks between Ukraine and the United States have been going on since the beginning of January. And for two weeks now, the United States has been holding talks with Russian counterparts as well.Both sides have been looking for solutions to the crisis. But the talks have been held behind closed doors, and there are rumors that the United States has given up on its demand to get a peace deal by the end of April.So far there has been a lot of positive talk. But all of that is all about how the talks will be conducted.On Monday, a statement was issued by the Foreign Ministers of the four countries—Ukraine, the United States, Russia, and Britain. They called for an immediate ceasefire and talks to begin immediately.If peace talks can't be held in the next few days, if they cannot be arranged in time before the end of the month, then what chance do the talks have now? And this does not mean that the talks won't work. But there's no real point in announcing that.There is no indication what those talks might entail. It's not clear what kind of peace plan the United States might be willing to accept. And there is no sign the United States has any real plan of its own.This week's talks have been taking place behind closed doors and behind the scenes. If they succeed, then everything should be fine. But at this point, the question is, what hope do the talks have?This is a story that's been playing out for weeks. And in the past two weeks there has been a lot of hope, especially when the talks were taking place behind closed doors.But then the talks were halted, and this was followed by another delay. And so on.

Refugees in Belgium are worried about the backlash they will face after the country’s prime minister said they could “only stay if they accept the conditions.”“There is no question about it: people will be afraid of being the scapegoat for anything that happens,” said Aisha Akef, who was originally from Somalia.Akef and her brother, who is from Eritrea, decided to settle in Belgium in 2016. They were granted asylum in 2017.However, they worry about the backlash that could happen when they speak their minds on social media about how they’re feeling and the challenges they’re having in adapting to their new life in Belgium.“When you say something and you think about it you realize it’s true, but people also have different perspectives and can react differently, so you have to learn to live with the things that are happening around you,” Akef said.The country’s premier, Jan Jambon, made the comments on Twitter in response to the criticism from a Belgian senator that his country would lose some of its multicultural nature if the country’s newcomers cannot adapt to the new way of life.According to reports, some lawmakers warned that their citizens would suffer from an influx of foreigners from Africa.Jambon responded that the country’s culture and history would be “lost” if the country cannot “accept the fact that it is not always like what you hear on the television, on the radio, in the cinema, in the supermarket, in the Internet, and in the movies.”The government promised last week that it will look into how to protect citizens who are “unwelcome” when their fellow citizens criticize the newcomers’ behavior.

- ReportsAn increase in attempts to reach the UK via the English Channel, a border policy under threat in Britain as London attempts to get away with the issue in international waters.According to the British government, the latest migrants are mostly from the Arab world in an effort to force British policy changes.More than 3,000 migrants have passed through French ports to reach the UK so far this year, which is already up 25 percent compared to the same period in 2018.The increase is blamed on the growing number of attempts to reach the British coast by crossing the English Channel.While the migrants have the right to enter, the British government's policy of only letting in non-EU nationals in an effort to secure the votes of the "leave" voters is being challenged in court.The French have agreed to allow an additional 200,000 migrants to be permanently resettled in France after their asylum applications are approved.The British government is currently appealing a ruling which requires the UK to take in 400,000 new Syrian refugees.The UK currently rejects all new asylum requests from citizens of the Muslim world and has refused to allow Syrians to settle in the country.Many believe that the increase in arrivals can be blamed on the growing number of Syrian refugee populations in Turkey, which they claim to have been "misled."The British government had already agreed to allow 10,000 Syrian refugees to settle in Britain.The British prime minister, Theresa May, has recently warned that any attempt to "disconnect" her country from the rest of the European Union would be a mistake.

PeopleBEIRUT (AP) — Three Syrian activists and two journalists said a deadly blast in the Syrian border town of Hassakeh near the Turkish border killed at least 5 people on Saturday.The activists and journalists spoke on condition of anonymity because they feared government reprisals.In the latest attack on the Syrian opposition-held border town of Hassakeh, a powerful blast went off Saturday morning and killed five people, the activists said.Local officials in Hassakeh said five people were killed in a rocket-propelled grenade explosion.It wasn’t immediately known whether the rocket struck at midday or when the blast took place. It was also unclear who fired the rocket.Syria’s President Bashar Assad’s government has fired thousands of rockets into the country in recent years, mostly targeting areas held by the opposition, including Hassakeh where a truce is held.In 2016, the Syrian military said its planes had killed “terrorists” on the Turkish border in the northern countryside, in one of its biggest successes against rebels in the fight against government forces.Turkey’s president Erdogan has repeatedly promised to send forces into Syrian territory to drive back the extremists.Syria’s civil war has left hundreds of thousands of people dead and tens of thousands injured.Syrian President Bashar Assad has also launched chemical attacks on his own citizens, allegedly killing dozens of people, a claim dismissed as fabrications by the international community.

of SpainSpanish political analyst and former guerrilla who rose from poverty to become a Spanish lawmaker hopes to become the country’s next leader.In a recent speech, former leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), Ivan Marquez said he hoped to be elected the next Spanish leader.The Spanish presidential election was first held in the country in 1975 and Marquez won over one million votes to become Spain’s leader.Spain will hold another presidential election in 2023 but Marquez will again be trying to break the political impasse that has plagued the country.For years, Marquez has been at the forefront of the failed process for Colombian independence from Spain. The Spanish government has ruled out supporting Colombian independence in favor of democratic consolidation.“I will not stand by the side of the Colombian people who suffer for a future without a future, nor that of Spain which needs to stand up against violence against people who live on the streets, the poor, and suffer discrimination because of their religion, race and gender,” said Marquez, according to the BBC.Marquez will run in the second round of the Spanish parliamentary election in April 2020.

KANO, Nigeria—At least 22 people were killed Friday by a suicide bombing in northern Nigeria at a mosque, police said, the first such attack in the country.A suicide bomber struck inside the mosque, in the city of Madagali in Kano, the police said.

Share via EmailShare Via TextShare Via TextShare Via EmailThe U.S. government has launched a major campaign to slash its reliance on salt-laden foods.In recent years, U.S. regulators have been increasingly concerned about the excess of salt added to the U.S. diet.Now, the government is issuing new guidelines that food processors will have to meet, or else face civil penalty, over their use of sodium.The Food and Drug Administration recently sent a letter to more than 30,000 food processors, asking them to take extra care in using sodium in their products.While more than half of the foods sold in the U.S. contain some form of salt, the FDA is worried that excessive salt levels can lead to heart disease and kidney failure, which are both extremely costly and life-threatening diseases.The move by the FDA is seen as an effort to reduce the number of American foods that contain too much salt.It also comes amid a debate over the growing influence of processed foods and the fact that many products in their stores contain more than just sodium.The FDA said last year that more than 1.5 billion sodium-containing foods were purchased in the U.S. each year. The agency estimates that more than 200 million Americans take medications that come with sodium.“It is our hope that these voluntary standards will provide the flexibility for manufacturers and producers to determine a consistent approach in meeting the requirements of the voluntary standards,” says FDA Commissioner David Kessler. “And our hope is that these standards will be used to help create a healthier food environment.”

: VideosA Syrian boy sits inside a shelter in Turkey's Aksehir camp. (Photo: AP)Turkey's Aksehir refugee camp hosts many people displaced by Syria's civil war, from all walks of life.Most camp residents are women and children from the war's shattered cities.The video below was shot by a Syrian boy inside the refugee camp.Aksehir, in northwestern Syria, is one of the largest refugee camps in the world, with nearly 80,000 people at its disposal. Aksehir was established in 1949.Some 20,000 Syrians fled the country after an attack on two villages by pro-Damascus forces. Many fled to the camp in mid-January, with many more arriving afterward.This child was a Syrian boy who escaped from the violence in his country. Aksehir was established in 1949.

in Time for School ClosingBlack Lives Matter flags have returned to a Vermont school flagpole.At the end of September, some signs with the black flag of Black Lives Matter (BLM) started showing up at schools all over the state.

LOS ANGELES (AP) — Actor Tim Conway, the veteran comic and actor best known for his character of "The Carol Burnett Show," has died after a fall at his home in Southern California. He was 85.His wife, Susan, told the AP that Conway died Wednesday evening.Conway's career as a comic began in the 1950s in the New York area. He appeared in such TV shows as “The Dick Van Dyke Show," “Frasier" and "Seinfeld."He was best known for his iconic role on the Burnett show, which ran from 1955 to 1967.Among his notable film appearances were “Batman,” “Jingle All the Way” and the cult classic “Beverly Hills Cop.”He also had a huge impact on the TV world as a stand-up comic in the 1960s.His first album was released in 1965 and he opened for comic comedians such as Jerry Lewis and Mel Brooks in Las Vegas.In 1970 he became a regular on “The Tonight Show” with Jay Leno and on some subsequent guest spots on the show.He was also active in politics throughout his career, including as an ambassador with the United States at the 1964 Olympics in the Tokyo games and later on as a US ambassador to the European Parliament, according to The Hollywood Reporter.Conway was a Los Angeles native, and his funeral is set for Friday at the Hollywood Palladium, according to his wife.

Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019 with Chinese tourists back on the Mainland.Tourism is one of the most important Chinese industries that has been decimated in recent years due to the COVID pandemic. While the Mainland does not have an overabundance of Broadway shows, the bubble is popping.Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019.Photo: Vivo Pictures/Getty ImagesAccording to a report from the Beijing tourism industry and exhibition center, the number of Chinese tourists to the Mainland, including both locals and tourists, has reached its peak.This report also said that for the first time since 2019, tourists visited the Mainland more frequently and the Mainland began to welcome more American tourists to the country.Broadway shows on the Mainland are gaining steam again for the first time since 2019.

When the President took office, he quickly approved a plan that would create a new option for students to have a small refundable tax credit, a first-time homebuyer loan, and a student-related refinancing option called "direct loan" which makes a student loan more affordable to the borrower.The move seemed to have the desired effect. Some college-bound students chose to attend a "better" school because they could get a better education.But now that some schools have taken steps to ease the path for paying off student loans, things are getting a little strange.According to CNBC, now that a law has been passed to allow students to "refinance" their student loans, schools are starting to take an increasingly hands-on approach in making sure that all students are paying their loans every day, even if they fail to complete classes. That includes offering students a "free" college education from the schools in their home states.But as the law is changing, schools are starting to create more complicated programs for the families of college-bound students. These kids are being forced out of their home states so that their families can attend institutions of higher education, even if they don't really need to attend because the schools in their states are so much better than the ones they'd have to attend to attend to them.The latest controversy arose in Utah, where one of the schools is offering this type of tuition-reduction package to parents of students who don't make it into the schools they want:Under the program, if a student does not graduate from at least one of the schools that meet the criteria, their parents are automatically enrolled in the program and receive tuition remission, but they will still need to work to cover the costs of attending the schools."I don't want to go to Utah now, I really don't, but they've got a program that they think it might be best for our daughter," said Laura Wilson, the mother of a high school student."

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky declared victory in the country's presidential election, a day after a second vote was ordered by the Supreme Election Commission.Zelensky took 63 percent of the vote in the first tally, and 74 percent in the second. In the initial count, an opposition candidate, Oleh Sentel, claimed he had won 57.8 percent of the vote.The second count was ordered a day after Zelensky won a majority in the parliament's first vote. The parliament is controlled by the opposition, who were demanding a second ballot.The head of the parliament's election commission said the outcome of the second vote was "in accordance with the rules of parliamentary politics."The election is to be held again on 25 April 2020, with the parliamentary election coming first.Zelensky is expected to win a second term but the results will be disputed.Zelensky says his "personal vision for the country" was met in the first round of the vote.President of Ukraine #VladimirZelensky wins by winning 63% of the popular vote in the 1st round of the presidential election.#IreneDoroshenko of the ruling party comes in a distant 2nd place with 22.3% of the vote and Yulia Tymoshenko, the leader of the opposition, came in 3rd with 17.1%.The presidential election is to be held again on 25 April 2020, with the parliamentary election coming first.President Zelensky is expected to win a second term but the results will be disputed.

BEIJING - China has celebrated the completion of a new bridge linking two major cities that had been gridlocked for decades.The two new bridges, the new Hong Kong-Macau Bridge linking Hong Kong’s Kowloon peninsula to Macau’s neighboring Hong Kong Island, and the new Beijing-Shenyang-Beijing Bridge linking the two capitals, were opened on Monday.Chinese Premier Li Keqiang led the opening ceremony for the bridge projects in Hong Kong and Macau with a ceremony to mark the start of construction work for the first three phases of the Kowloon-Macau bridge.The two new bridges connect Hong Kong with Kowloon, linking the capital cities of the two Asian financial hubs, China’s largest international financial and trade center.The bridge is a critical part of a multi-city, integrated transport system in Hong Kong, an important global city which is also an important hub for trade with mainland China.The main tunnel connecting the two cities will run alongside the current Kowloon-Macao bridge, allowing people to travel between the two cities in half the time, allowing a greater degree of connectivity across the city.It is also the only one-stop bridge connecting both cities.The first three phases of the Hong Kong-Macau bridge will have a total capacity of 4,000 people per hour.The three-phase bridge, which is expected to open by the end of 2017, will cost HK$17 billion ($2.05 billion) and will serve 1.8 million vehicles per day.The second leg of the two-city bridge, which is scheduled to be completed in 2022, will increase capacity to 1.8 million vehicles.

, Withdraws Troops From Asian NationWASHINGTON — The United States on Thursday suspended all economic sanctions against Burma, the junta leader."I signed an executive order to suspend certain economic and financial sanctions in Burma against the military junta in response to Burma's military coup," Trump tweeted.In another statement, the US Treasury Department said that "it is critical that Burma's military leader, Min Aung Hlaing, be removed from power.""The military government in Burma has been engaged in human rights abuses and should immediately address all restrictions on the people," it added.According to the Treasury Department, the suspension means that "the United States will not use any U.S. resources or military support to aid the Burmese military's efforts to take control of the civilian government in Burma."In a sign of the US' shift, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Thursday that the US is "going to get out of that type of commitment," Bloomberg reported.As many as 13,000 US troops remain in the Asian country, but "that number is expected to go down," Biden said, without specifying how.The Biden administration also announced that in a "positive step," the two governments signed an agreement for the United States to remove its remaining troops from South Korea, the first step in a formal diplomatic process that could lead to more American military withdrawal.While the Pentagon had no immediate comment on Austin's comments, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Thursday that the US is "going to get out of that type of commitment," Bloomberg reported.According to Politico, sources familiar with US-North Korea policy said the administration is now actively exploring ways to ensure continued security support for the regime as the Kim Jong-un regime increasingly looks weak.US envoy for denuclearization, Ambassador Matthew Ward, told reporters, "If the North Koreans aren't going to play along, you have to find another way."The US also plans to remove remaining troops from South Korea, two senior Biden administration officials said on Thursday, without providing details.

TUNIS (AP) — Tunisia’s prime minister on Wednesday announced a new government to form after weeks of political chaos since an anti-government movement pushed Tunisia’s president to step down.Mustafa Jazid led the secular, liberal government in a ceremony that was broadcast live on state television.Jazid urged the new government to immediately form a new cabinet and hold elections to give the nation’s population a “clear choice” between the current administration or a new government.Jazid, a 60-year-old technocrat, is a former interior minister under former autocrat Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, who was Tunisia’s head of state for 21 years.He had pledged to be a bridge to a younger generation disillusioned with Tunisia’s autocratic politics and its entrenched political system.Tunisian President Beji Caid Essebsi announced the formation of the government at the beginning of March, but Jazid’s appointment was delayed by weeks until the prime minister was confirmed.Essebsi said that “the new government must be as transparent as possible, and all the necessary funds to ensure the citizens’ development.”“

- WNKY.com | Louisville News, Weather and SportsA Nigerian militant group has released nearly 900 kidnapped children as part of a massive amnesty program.Islamic Republic of Nigeria Boko Haram has released most of the 900 schoolchildren it has seized, an aid group says.The children were freed in the largest amnesty granted to hostages held by the group.The release comes in the face of growing criticism of Boko Haram's activities.In a statement on Wednesday, the group said it had released nearly 900 of the children it had kept in captivity over the past 18 months.The children were released "in order to serve the betterment and the education of the whole human family," the militants' Amadou Bakassi faction said.In exchange, the group said it would release several hundred hostages it has kept since last year."We call on the military and the authorities to end this brutal conflict so that all the people of this great and magnificent nation will be safe," the militants' statement said.No date was given for when the mass release will take place.The release comes at a time when Nigeria's army has been battling rebels in the north, while neighboring countries are concerned that the country's security is not improving.Copyright 2018 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.

Position in the Party[Taiwan News] – A senior aide of President Tsai Ing-wen and former Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida is believed to be preparing to take over the leadership role in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), according to various media reports.Both Fumio Kishida and Tsai have been rumored to be considering running for the leadership in the DPP as of late.Fumio Kishida was known to be among a group of former DPP vice presidents that Tsai chose to head the party’s new internal affairs committee.Kishida later decided not to go through with it, according to people close to the administration.“The next chairman will need to be someone who will have the most support from other DPP members in the coming election,” said Kishida’s close friend, who requested anonymity.“Kishida had his friends among DPP members who were in favor of him as the chairman.”Tsai’s camp has expressed an interest in Fumio Kishida’s name to take over.Tsai has said he will be stepping down as president sometime after July 28.

IndustryA recent development in India’s fashion industry includes technology as one of the major trends shaping the future of fashion design. The advancement of technology is making it easier to create fashion wear and products which have already been incorporated in some of the leading brands. For instance, in 2015, Apple introduced the Apple Watch which is a popular technology based wear. The watch is equipped with different sensors which enable the users to monitor a lot of data about themselves. For example, the watch can send a message when the user is running out of time. There are apps available which are installed on the Apple Watch which can make the user stay connected with them anytime anywhere. Similarly, the smart watch can detect the temperature and can be adjusted according to the body’s needs. The watch can control the music and make call so that the user gets more information than can be communicated with human voice. These devices make fashion wear available in an even more sophisticated manner.The trend of using technology in fashion is also increasing as more consumers prefer to shop online. A study in 2016 reveals that almost 80% of all people today use computers to buy fashion and they also use technology to access their personal information. These devices enable the customers to stay connected with the brands they like.For instance, the Amazon app for android users, is a very popular application which enables the user to buy anything from Amazon.com even though not a huge number of people use this application for the purpose.The latest fashion trends also incorporate technology in their designs. In some cases, there is no visible change in the design but in some cases, there are changes happening. For example, an electronic wrist band such as an Apple Watch can be used to provide information about the wearer. Similar technology can be incorporated in the latest designs.With technology becoming more mainstream in fashion, consumers are not only consuming the latest trends but also buying them.In 2016, there were more than 70 million wearable devices that were sold. Some of these wearables even run software which controls the device. These electronic devices are becoming more and more popular.For instance, in 2013, a new Apple Watch was launched in order to provide an even more advanced level of functionality. This watch is able to collect data from the wearer and also be used to make calls and send text messages.The future of fashion is certainly going to be a lot of interesting developments involving technology and design.

for UseIt seems like the latest charitable intervention is the offer of a Compassionate Care Award. The first of the year, and the second awarded by HumanKind, compels you to spend some time on this site, then to post an online question “about yourself.” You need to think hard about what you are doing and what you want to achieve before you leave this page. The purpose is to help people get to know you, and to give you some insight into who you are and what you want to accomplish. You may be asked to elaborate, but you can say you already know who you want to be about yourself, that you already have some good ideas about what you want to do. You can give yourself some good advice. You may be asked to explain why you do your current work and what you are trying to do. Perhaps you can tell people what you have learned about yourself, or what you have learned from the people you have come into contact with. I hope, by writing this, I can answer your questions about yourself and make yourself seem more of a “person” than a “gimmick,” and a “pseudoperson.”The second Compassionate Care Award Award for the year, a few days before I was told by HumanKind that I could ask any “organization, charity or organization” to write me about myself, is supposed to be a “test.” What does that mean? I want to see what is really behind what I am doing and what I say. This is to help me see how far my “passive” self has “passive” feelings and a “passive” character that “passive” feelings don’t have. It isn’t necessarily that I am asking you to tell me what is going on in your life, but it does allow me to learn from what you write, and from what I write about you. This kind of “test” doesn’t tell you who you are, because you don’t write about a “you” and tell a “me” of who you want to be.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — A former Khmer Rouge officer was arraigned on Tuesday at a central Cambodian court for questioning about alleged crimes during the Vietnam War.A phalanx of men in green jumpsuits, khaki shirts and dark trousers escorted Lt. Gen. Phong Sokol.He was arrested in Cambodia on Monday by Cambodian troops who arrived on military aircraft.Khmer Rouge member and former commander of the notorious Vietnam War-era army, the International Military Tribunal for the Former Khmer Rouge, (ITF) for the crimes committed at the hands of the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, Phong Sokol. He was in the country of his own accord, without being asked to or seeking asylum.On June 28, a court announced that Phong Sokol will be transferred to Cambodia for questioning. He had been living in Cambodia for a decade.Phong Sokol led the Khmer Rouge regime from 1975-1979 and is a wanted fugitive under the International Military Tribunal for the Former Khmer Rouge and other countries.The tribunal ruled that the Khmer Rouge were responsible for more than 1 million deaths, mainly of civilians, during the Vietnam War.In a statement by his office, Phong Sokol said that while "he did not have any intention to incriminate the Cambodian government," he has nevertheless been asked to come for questioning due to an intelligence report regarding an event that happened years ago.Phong Sokol stated that his defense lawyer has already been called as a witness."

- But Will That Be Enough To Disprove Occupy Wall Street?Occupy Boston continues to grow as protesters march towards Zuccotti Park, with many calling for a general strike against the current corporate-run government, even though there's a distinct possibility that any such action would only be a symbolic protest against the police. But a quick glance at Occupy Boston's Facebook page reveals dozens of arrests. And even if the numbers of people who are arrested are significantly smaller than some people believe, will that be enough to completely shut down Occupy Wall Street? And what do those people who were arrested do now?We got word that over 100 arrests were made throughout the downtown areas of Boston on Wednesday, including 50 arrests in Zuccotti Park alone. According to Occupy Boston's Facebook page, "police came in with guns in hand" and took several people away in handcuffs for "assault and riot," though those charges have yet to be filed.

MindanaoMANILA (Reuters) - Philippine troops killed three members of a local communist rebel group in South Mindanao on Tuesday, the military said, in a new push by the government to curb a long-running insurgency.Three communist rebels, including a group leader, were killed by troops during a gunbattle near the town of Iriga in southern Mindanao, the military said.The rebels were attempting to cross a mountain pass at Iriga when they were caught by government forces, the military said."

http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/breitbart/~3/zfXkG4r_V_Y/Director of National Intelligence John Bolton predicted Tuesday that U.S.-Russia ties would improve after President Joe Biden’s meetings with Russian President Vladimir Putin and that Biden would agree to meet next month in Paris with Putin.When asked about a meeting between the two leaders in Paris to discuss the coronavirus and other issues, Bolton said “certainly I see that we’ll have an agreement to meet.”“And then in Paris I believe we’re going to have a summit,” the former ambassador to the United Nations said.Bolton told NBC’s Today show that he had heard the idea from Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov.“There’s been a number of meetings between our foreign ministers over the last six months, some of them in Paris,” Bolton said. “And I think we’re on track to have a meeting.”He said Biden and Putin had agreed to resume the strategic dialogue between the United States and Russia that was cut off by former President Donald Trump.He said the two presidents would consider working together to “address serious issues facing our world.”

Islamabad, (UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 18th Dec, 2019 ) :Pakistan has strongly rejected claims made by Afghanistan that it is aiding the Taliban militants behind a series of deadly attacks that have struck the Islamic republic ahead of legislative and presidential elections.Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani claimed Thursday that "several hundred" Taliban fighters were responsible for the November 8 attacks which killed 28 civilians and wounded 79 others, and that the perpetrators were from Pakistani and Afghan military personnel.His comments prompted a furious denunciation from Pakistan, which has long fought Taliban violence."We reject such baseless claims as we categorically reject any group, including the Taliban, inimical to the security of Afghanistan," Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi said in a statement, adding that the Pakistani military and security forces "never engage in acts of terrorism".Qureshi said Afghanistan's President Ghani's claims were "not only unfounded but also dangerous"."The recent attacks in Afghanistan are a clear message that the international community is not safe and secure," he added.Pakistan has long blamed Taliban attacks on Afghanistan, often including deadly suicide bombings, on Pakistani troops and intelligence.Pakistan and Afghanistan agreed in 2016 to cut all ties and relations over the violence in the region, but have continued to be involved in military operations against the Taliban.Since September 2014, Afghan security forces have killed at least 17 Pakistani troops during operations against Taliban strongholds, according to Pakistani security sources.

The same survey shows many Venezuelans are also opposed to the constitution. They argue the document has been the cause of the political conflict in the country.According to a new poll, about 85 percent of Venezuelans want the Venezuelan Constitution Revision Committee to make changes to the document.The survey, conducted between November 9 and November 14, polled 4,000 people through an interactive digital tool that enables a voter to rank issues in a list.The document, which was written in 1983, is the fourth to the eighth in the country's 27-year constitution. However, it was ratified in 1994 and has been amended several times since.In 2011, a court ordered that some laws should not have been ratified, including a law on the country's Constitution.Some 70,000 protesters in Caracas in 2012 called for the government to remove certain articles of the constitution, which they argued were unconstitutional because they did not follow certain rules.Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, whose father was the president for 15 years before leaving in 1981, is seeking to replace the Constitution. He has repeatedly called for a referendum.But the country's Supreme Court has dismissed calls for a new referendum in the past, citing the nation's political crisis.Many Venezuelans feel that the constitution, which was ratified in 1974, has not been implemented well.Many blame the country's crisis, which includes high inflation, food shortages and rampant crime, on the document.Most also believe the country is heading for a civil war.This is not the first time an online poll has revealed Venezuelans' attitudes on the constitution.An online poll conducted by the government in November 2013 found that about 75 percent of Venezuelans believe the constitution is "unbalanced," while another 21 percent said it is "balanced."

- ReportBERLIN — The initial investigation of the Germanwings pilot who caused the crash of a passenger plane into the Alps last year shows that a senior executive at Germany’s biggest airline has been accused of recklessly violating flight safety laws, the newspaper Die Zeit reported on Sunday.According to the report, Christian Smoltz, the chief of the management board of Swiss-based airline Swiss International Airlines, was aware of an inspection on one of the plane’s engines in 2009, but failed to implement it.The report cited several unnamed sources familiar with the matter, including an aviation source who also served as a witness in the initial inquiry in April.“This is an area in which Swiss International was responsible for several years,” the source said.In addition to the first official inquiry, another investigation into the crash, launched this past fall, revealed numerous shortcomings in Germanwings’ maintenance and control process.In 2015, Swiss International started a program in which employees were required to be informed on all Germanwings maintenance operations, according to the newspaper. But the airline did not submit maintenance reports to the regulatory agency until February 2016.

Sen. John McCain has a reputation for being an old, hardy fighter. But on the eve of his 83rd birthday, the Arizona Republican is still willing to spend his days on the floor of the Senate debating health care.Even though he's admitted to battling a rare form of cancer that's affecting his brain and lungs, McCain has kept fighting for the Senate's bill that would allow Americans to keep their current insurance plans even if they lose their jobs."I'd be lying to you if I said there hasn't been a debate or discussion about this bill," said Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, who is helping to draft the legislation."The key points in all these conversations has been to make sure that people can keep their health care plan," Lee told reporters on the sidelines of a bill-writing forum on Monday. "It's a question of whether we have the ability to find a common ground that can move through this Congress. We just hope that as many Republicans and as many Democrats as possible can come to the table and support this bill."The legislation has a good chance of getting the 60 votes needed to pass the Senate. It was narrowly approved for consideration last week in the House, but it's uncertain how strong the support will be in the Senate.McCain's fellow Arizona Republican, Sen. Jeff Flake, said he is committed to working with his colleague, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, to try and pass the legislation."I believe strongly in this, and I know that Orrin Hatch will work with me on it, to get this bill across the finish line," Flake told a gathering at the John McCain Presidential Library on Monday. "It's hard. You have to convince a lot of people. But I am convinced that it needs to happen."The legislation still faces a tough hurdle. Some senators have already said they will filibuster the measure once it reaches the Senate floor, and other moderate Republicans are worried about the bill's tax-hike elements.Still, McCain remains a stalwart, and on Monday, Hatch said it's still possible the legislation will be approved."I don't think it's all that difficult to pass this bill if you have a really good bill written to make sure people can keep their current plans," said Hatch, the No. 2 Republican in the chamber.

WASHINGTON -- The United States has issued what could be a tough warning to Palestinians who may see Israel's move toward full membership in the Jewish state as a green light to push for a more violent Palestinian uprising.U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the administration was concerned that recent developments in Israel's peace process could lead to a Palestinian uprising.In recent days, Israel has signed the agreements to give up much of its pre-1967 borders and give Palestinians some self-rule over the territory of the new state. U.S. officials have cautioned that Hamas, a radical Islamist organization that has ruled Gaza since 2006, could use the deal to cement control over the territory. They say such a move could escalate the situation by empowering Hamas, which currently controls Gaza, as a major player in the Palestinian peace process."Any movement along that line could be dangerous," a U.S. official said, calling the situation a "serious" one.The Israeli government has expressed satisfaction with the agreement, but has said it still wants full membership in the United Nations, and a Palestinian state at peace with Israel.A U.S. official said the U.S. government will be willing to provide economic assistance to Israel and its Jewish neighbors in the absence of a Palestinian state, and would do so to help both Jewish Israelis and Jewish Palestinians who support Israel.

Over ElectionSouth Africa's main opposition party staged protests outside President Cyril Ramaphosa's official residence on Thursday over alleged irregularities in the March 8 presidential election.The main opposition Democratic Alliance party (DA) said the results of the presidential poll were "illegitimate" and they "hope" that Ramaphosa will step down if he does not accept the results.On Thursday, the DA was joined by the ruling African National Congress (ANC) and other political parties and thousands of people from various walks of life, including unions, trade unions, religious bodies and media houses.This week's protests come after the South African court upheld a request by the Electoral Commission to allow a petition to be presented before a special court to challenge the election result.In the petition, the Constitutional Court ordered the Electoral Commission (IEC) to produce evidence for the court to consider to decide whether there were significant irregularities or malfeasance in the voting process in the South African election.The court also ordered that the commission not present any evidence before the special court until a final decision by the court is made.The petition has been supported by the South Africa branch of the International Federation of Free Democrats (FDD).The petition was opposed by the ruling African National Congress, which has argued that the IEC failed to do its job properly and should be replaced by a party that does its job properly."The president of the ANC has also indicated that he does not want to accept the results, not even if they are in the interests of his party," the DA said."The current leadership of the ANC has demonstrated an abject failure to provide for the needs and interests of the people," the DA said.The party said there were "no grounds whatsoever" to suspect the outcome of the presidential election was fraudulently manipulated."The public, which has come to know the facts, can and should expect President Ramaphosa to resign if the results were not in the people's interests," the DA said.The party said that there was sufficient evidence to suggest that the election was rigged and there was "clearly a systematic and planned effort to rig the results".The EFF in a statement in support of the DA said that the party would hold protests until the results were accepted."

WASHINGTON - John McCain is not signing off quietly.As in so much of the senator's extraordinary life, the rebellious Republican is facing this challenging chapter -- battling brain cancer -- in his own rule-breaking way, stirring up old fights and starting new ones. Rarely has the sickbed been so lively.McCain is promoting a new book, delivering a counterpunch of ideals contrary to President Donald Trump's running of the White House. McCain's long-distance rejection of CIA director nominee Gina Haspel's history with torture goaded former Vice President Dick Cheney into a fresh debate over waterboarding and other now-banned interrogation techniques. On Friday, friends rallied to defend McCain against a White House official's cruel joke that his positions don't matter because ``he's dying anyway.''If this is Washington's long goodbye to a sometimes favorite son, it's also a reemergence of old resentments and political fault lines that continue to split the nation.Perhaps no one should have expected anything less from the 81-year-old senator, who can be crotchety and cantankerous but is also seen by many, both in and out of politics, as an American hero, flaws and all.Former Vice President Joe Biden said Friday as McCain ``fights for his life, he deserves better -- so much better.''``Our children learn from our example,'' Biden said. ``The lingering question is: Whose example will it be? I am certain it will be John's.''Said House Speaker Paul Ryan, ``His legacy is so long that John McCain is a hero to us all.''

Thousands of Austrians are protesting their country's new right-wing government with a march in Vienna. Police in the capital said about 20,000 people were attending the march on Saturday. Some protesters carried placards reading "Never Again." Others chanted slogans such as "Refugees should stay, drive out the Nazis." The new governing coalition made up of the conservative Austrian People's Party and the nationalist Freedom Party has taken a hard line against migration.

LONDON - President Donald Trump on Friday declared the U.S. relationship with Britain as “the highest level of special,” rejecting reports of troubled ties further frayed by his comments published in one of the highest-circulation newspapers in this country.Standing alongside the British prime minister outside her Chequers country estate, Trump defended his remarks in the newspaper interview, which were seen as further weakening Theresa May’s hold on power.“It didn’t put in what I said about the prime minister and I said tremendous things,” Trump replied to a question about critical remarks he made in an interview with The Sun.WATCH: Brits Protest Trump VisitThe conservative British newspaper itself characterized Trump’s printed remarks as pouring nitroglycerine on the already raging revolt against the prime minister by Brexit hardliners in May’s own party.“They didn’t put it in the headline," Trump said about positive comments he made about May during the interview. "I wish they put it in the headline."Trump then alluded to “fake news,” but he did not specifically deny any of his comments printed by the newspaper, whose Friday morning headline blared: “May has wrecked Brexit…US deal is off!”But Trump on Friday afternoon said that after his discussions with May and her aides, he now believes a post-Brexit free trade agreement between Washington and London is “absolutely possible.”

Ukraine's emergencies ministry says 16 miners have been killed in an explosion at a mine in the country's east.The ministry said three other miners were injured in the blast early Friday morning and hospitalized, while nine were missing. The explosion occurred at a mine in the Luhansk region.

BRUSSELS - By the time he made it from Syria to Europe, 25-year-old Mulham, like many new arrivals, was already distrustful of authorities.In Croatia, for example, police told his group they were going to a hotel to shower and sleep.Instead, they were locked inside what smelled like a large barn, and held for seven hours."I asked the police what was happening," Mulham said later as we drank coffee at a ramshackle café near a refugee camp in Belgium."The officer told me: We don't want you,” he said. "The world doesn't want you.'"But Mulham feels that, with a degree in architecture and the strength and resources to escape Syria, the comment is unjust. "I will be useful after all," he asserted.As tanks roll through the streets of Brussels, and heavily armed officers patrol areas they believe will be targeted in what the government calls an "imminent threat" of a terrorist attack or attacks, Mulham remains skeptical.Refugees play football Nov. 23, 2015, near a Brussels camp. The soldiers and tanks guarding the city were not in the neighborhood. (Heather Murdock/VOA)Many Syrian refugees are afraid of the attacks and depressed to be facing the threat of violence again after fleeing a brutal war, he said. But Mulham and many others simply don't believe there is a threat."They want to make the people afraid of us," he said, mulling alternate reasons for the show of force. He considers another possibility: Authorities want to make refugees afraid of backlash from the local people.And that is the impact the heightened alert is having, regardless of the reason for it, said 19-year-old Adel, a Syrian refugee in Belgium who hopes to one day play football (soccer) professionally.

U.S. President George Bush is urging an end to the fighting in Georgia's breakaway province of South Ossetia. VOA White House correspondent Paula Wolfson reports from Beijing, where Mr. Bush is attending the Olympic Games.President Bush says the fighting must stop."I am deeply concerned about the situation in Georgia," he said. "The United States takes this matter very seriously."He says he is particularly troubled by the fact the conflict is spreading to other parts of Georgia - a reference to Russian bombings beyond the borders of South Ossetia."The violence is endangering regional peace," said President Bush. "Civilian lives have been lost and others are endangered."South Ossetia's autonomous status was abolished by the Georgian government in 1990, then reinstated in 1992. The current government in Tblisi has vowed to bring it back into the fold and on Thursday launched a military operation to do just that.But South Ossetia has strong ties to Moscow, which supports the separatist movement. When Georgia sent its forces in, the Russians responded by sending in more troops and bombers.President Bush says all sides need to step back, stop hostilities, and work with mediators to resolve the conflict."Georgia is a sovereign nation and its territorial integrity must be respected," he said. "We have urged an immediate halt to the violence and a stand-down by all troops."White House officials say President Bush re-enforced the U.S. position in separate conversations with Russian President Dmitri Medvedev, and Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili.
